news.title: How Trump changed tack in Minnesota after Pretti's death
news.text:
WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî President Donald Trump shifted toward a more conciliatory approach with Democratic leaders in Minnesota on Monday, a sudden change in tack following an outcry over the second fatal shooting of a protester by federal agents this month during the administration‚Äôs nationwide crackdown on undocumented immigrants.

The about-face comes after Saturday‚Äôs shooting death of Alex Pretti by federal agents raised doubts ‚Äî including from some Republicans ‚Äî over how the Trump administration has gone about aggressively deporting migrants and confronting protesters opposed to the policy.

But it‚Äôs just the latest in a string of moments where Trump has first taken a maximalist position only to appear to later retreat.

Earlier this month, Trump repeatedly threatened Iran with military action if his administration found the Islamic Republic was using deadly force to squelch recent antigovernment protests. Human rights groups said thousands were killed, but Trump says he‚Äôs holding off on acting after he received assurances Tehran was suspending hundreds of planned executions.

Last week, Trump first announced plans to impose new tariffs on European allies that refused to go along with his calls for the U.S. to take control of the Arctic territory of Greenland ‚Äî only to abruptly cancel the tariffs after saying he‚Äôd come to terms of the ‚Äúframework‚Äù of an agreement. The White House offered scant details about the deal, which Trump announced the day after the stock market saw one of its worst days in months in response to his tariff threat.

Then on Monday, Trump‚Äôs administration changed up oversight of his immigration operation in Minnesota, and the typically bombastic Trump offered a warmer tone toward Gov. Tim Walz after speaking with the Democrat, saying he and Walz were now on a ‚Äúsimilar wavelength.‚Äù

Some Republicans took issue with what happened in Minneapolis

It was a particularly jarring turnabout for Trump, who had promised to be uncompromising on carrying out mass deportations of undocumented migrants during his 2024 campaign ‚Äî and because Trump has repeatedly scorched Walz and other Minnesota Democrats in personal terms for resisting his policies.

Trump said he had dispatched border czar Tom Homan to take charge. Meanwhile, senior Border Patrol commander Greg Bovino and some agents were expected to leave Minneapolis as early as Tuesday, according to a person familiar with the matter. 

Trump declared on social media that Walz ‚Äúwas happy that Tom Homan was going to Minnesota, and so am I!‚Äù Later, Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey confirmed that some agents would be leaving the city after he spoke with Trump ‚Äî and suggested that the president seemed to be coming to the conclusion that the current state of federal operations was unsustainable. Homan and Frey were expected to meet Tuesday.

Trump‚Äôs change-up in Minnesota came after some Republicans questioned federal agents‚Äô tactics in Saturday‚Äôs incident as well as the White House‚Äôs response. Some high-ranking administration officials had branded Pretti a domestic terrorist even as videos of the encounter contradicted their narrative.

Minnesota gubernatorial candidate Chris Madel, a Minneapolis attorney, ended his GOP campaign in a surprise video announcement Monday, calling the recent immigration enforcement operation in the Twin Cities an ‚Äúunmitigated disaster‚Äù and saying he no longer wanted to be a member of the party because of it.

Meanwhile, Texas Republican Gov. Greg Abbott, who has been a strong supporter of Trump‚Äôs crackdown on immigration, offered measured criticism in an interview with conservative radio host Mark Davis, saying the White House needs to ‚Äúrecalibrate‚Äù what it was doing in Minnesota. Vermont‚Äôs Republican Gov. Phil Scott called on Trump to reset and de-escalate.

‚ÄúAt best, these federal immigration operations are a complete failure of coordination of acceptable public safety and law enforcement practices training, and leadership,‚Äù Scott said. ‚ÄúAt worst, it‚Äôs a deliberate federal intimidation and incitement of American citizens that‚Äôs resulting in the murder of Americans.‚Äù

Trump had scorched Walz. Now, they‚Äôre on a ‚Äòsimilar wavelength‚Äô

The president‚Äôs approach toward Walz, who served as Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris‚Äô running mate in 2024, amounted to a sharp U-turn.

Just a day earlier, Trump‚Äôs deputy chief of staff, Stephen Miller, had derided Walz on social media as trying to ‚Äúincite attacks on‚Äù U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents. The White House social media team in a series of posts called the governor ‚Äúa truly disturbed, unstable individual‚Äù and an ‚Äúunhinged lunatic‚Äù who ‚Äúrants and raves and lies.‚Äù

Miller also referred to Pretti, a nurse who worked at a Veterans Affairs hospital, as a ‚Äúwould-be assassin‚Äù while Homeland Security Kristi Noem labeled the ICU nurse as committing an act of domestic terrorism.

The White House sidestepped whether Trump agreed with his senior aides‚Äô rhetoric or whether the administration would apologize for it.

‚ÄúThis incident remains under investigation,‚Äù press secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters. ‚ÄúAnd nobody here at the White House, including the president of the United States, wants to see Americans hurt or killed and losing their lives.‚Äù

His response has been muted compared to other recent deaths

Trump‚Äôs response to the deaths of the two U.S. citizens protesting in Minneapolis has been much more muted than reactions to political violence that he‚Äôs portrayed as targeting his own political movement.

After conservative activist Charlie Kirk was assassinated in September, the president spoke to the nation from the Oval Office and called Kirk‚Äôs death ‚Äúa dark moment for America.‚Äù 

In November, Trump gave a national address after two National Guard members were shot in Washington, D.C., by an Afghan national, one fatally. The guard members had been deployed to the nation‚Äôs capital as part of a federal mission to assist with local policing, and the president called the shooting ‚Äúan act of evil, an act of hatred and an act of terror.‚Äù

But the president has yet to speak directly to the nation about the deaths in Minneapolis of Pretti and Renee Good, another protester who was killed by federal agents in Minneapolis earlier this month. Trump has so far largely chosen to keep the public informed in the wake of Pretti‚Äôs death with social media posts.

Even as his comments Monday appeared to be aimed at turning down the rhetoric, Trump‚Äôs chief spokesperson, Leavitt, continued to blame Walz and other Minnesota Democrats for encouraging ‚Äúleft-wing agitators to stop, record, confront and obstruct federal officers who are just trying to lawfully perform their duties.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is precisely what unfolded in Minneapolis on Saturday morning,‚Äù Leavitt added.

AP writers Josh Boak and Joey Cappelletti in Washington, Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas, and Scott Bauer in Madison, Wisconsin, contributed reporting. Karnowski reported from Minneapolis.
news.author: Aamer Madhani,Steve Karnowski

news.title: Noem in the hot seat after Minneapolis shooting
news.text:
Noem has butted heads previously with Homan on how to approach enforcement. Homan, who spent most of his career working as an immigration officer, has pushed to protect ICE as an institution and focus efforts on deporting unauthorized immigrants with criminal records. Noem, meanwhile, has focused on using social media to project an image of exceedingly aggressive immigration enforcement.

Noem also elevated Border Patrol commander Gregory Bovino to serve as the essential head of operations in Minneapolis. Leavitt told reporters Monday that Homan, not Bovino, would be the ‚Äúmain point of contact‚Äù going forward in Minneapolis. Bovino is also being moved out of Minneapolis, an administration official told POLITICO.

DHS did not respond to a request for comment. Noem has said little since Trump distanced himself from the shooting on Sunday night, but she praised Trump‚Äôs decision to send Homan to Minneapolis in a social media post on Monday.

Some in the administration were already frustrated with Noem‚Äôs reaction to the shooting of 37-year-old Nicole Good on Jan. 7, also in Minneapolis. The DHS chief seemingly rushed to respond to that incident before all the facts were known. In the days after that shooting, ICE Deputy Director Madison Sheahan, a Noem ally who ran South Dakota‚Äôs Republican Party when Noem was the state‚Äôs governor, left her post in January to run for Congress in Ohio.

Voters have soured on the Trump administration‚Äôs immigration crackdown in recent months. Republican polling firm Echelon Insights found in a survey of registered voters published Monday that more people now say ICE operations in public areas make them feel unsafe, a drop from their findings a few months ago when attitudes were more evenly split.

Meanwhile, on Capitol Hill, Democrats have ramped up calls for Noem to resign or face impeachment proceedings over the way ICE and Border Patrol have conducted immigration enforcement operations and for allegedly mismanaging a major infusion of federal funds into the department allocated via the One Big Beautiful Bill.

Other Republican lawmakers, while not naming Noem, have called on the agency leaders that report to her to testify. Some, such as House Homeland Security Chair Andrew Garbarino (R-N.Y.), represent states or congressional districts where Trump only narrowly defeated former Vice President Kamala Harris in the 2024 elections.

Despite the growing pressure on Noem, Krikorian argued she‚Äôs unlikely to be ousted.

‚ÄúIt would be a win for the anti-border radicals‚Äù and ‚Äúembolden‚Äù efforts to resist ICE operations elsewhere, Krikorian said.

Dasha Burns and Myah Ward contributed to this report.
news.author: Eric Bazail-Eimil

news.title: Washington Post Braces for Massive Layoffs
news.text:
Last week there were reports that a big round of layoffs was about to be unveiled at the Washington Post. Some stores suggested the entire Sports staff was going to be removed.

Staffers at The Post are questioning Bezos and publisher Will Lewis‚Äô commitment to the health of the paper‚Äîand publicly pleading for them to change course‚Äîas they brace for upwards of 100 newsroom layoffs that are expected to hit the sports, metro and foreign teams hardest, according to multiple people familiar with the matter. As of August, the newsroom headcount sat around 800 staffers. Including those anticipated newsroom cuts, as many as 300 Post employees across the broader company could be impacted by the February trim-down, Status has learned.Spokespersons for The Post did not respond to multiple requests for comment for this story.‚ÄúThe newsroom is being punished for absolute incompetence from the owner and publisher,‚Äù one Post staffer said.

The report goes on to say that the Post would not be sending a team of reporters to cover the Winter Olympics despite having already paid for their travel and lodging. But a new story from the NY Times says the Post is reversing course on that decision though it will only be sending a handful of reporters.

The newspaper originally intended to send more than a dozen journalists to cover the event, which has long been a major priority for The Post. Those employees were notified in a terse email on Friday, less than three weeks before the Olympics begin, that The Post would not send any of them.Now, The Post expects to send four journalists, according to three people with knowledge of the decision. A spokeswoman for The Post confirmed the paper would be sending a small contingent.

Also worried about the cuts are the paper's foreign correspondents. The have sent a collective letter to Jeff Bezos asking him to, essentially, keep pouring money into the paper. Erik Wemple tweeted out the letter yesterday:

It says that The Post‚Äôs ‚Äúaward-winning international team regularly scoops and outshines the New York Times, Wall Street Journal and other major news outlets, despite already having significantly fewer reporters.‚Äù‚Äî ErikWemple (@ErikWemple) January 25, 2026

The letter says that the staffers are committed to cutting costs while working to retain ‚Äúas many jobs as we can.‚Äù It also mentions the key role of local staff overseas, whose ‚Äúlanguage skills and experience amplify the power of our journalism.‚Äù‚Äî ErikWemple (@ErikWemple) January 25, 2026

There are scores of signatories, and they include senior correspondents such as Greg Miller, Anthony Faiola, Souad Mekhennet, Siobh√°n O‚ÄôGrady, Shibani Mahtani and Yeganeh Torbati. Together they cover an astounding swath of global terrain.‚Äî ErikWemple (@ErikWemple) January 25, 2026

Individual reporters are also appealing to Bezos using the hashtag #SaveThePost:

Hi @JeffBezos. We will never forget your support for our essential work documenting the war in Ukraine, which still rages. Your wife has called our team ‚Äúbadass beacons of hope.‚Äù We risk our lives for the stories our readers demand. Please believe in us and #SaveThePost. pic.twitter.com/LH8lyGiU6M‚Äî Siobh√°n O'Grady (@siobhan_ogrady) January 26, 2026

.@jeffbezos I cover Iran for @washingtonpost. Since June, I've reported on US/Israeli strikes, a dire water crisis, state coercion of the private sector, and now, horrific govt violence against protesters. I want nothing more than to keep doing this important work. #SaveThePost pic.twitter.com/lb8Qe56L1k‚Äî Yeganeh Torbati (@yjtorbati) January 26, 2026

.@JeffBezos I cover international security for @washingtonpost and reported on ISIS, Jamal Khashoggi‚Äôs murder, al-Qaeda, Iran and Israel. I‚Äôve been imprisoned, lived under threats, and escaped kidnappings to do this work. #Journalism matters to America and the world. #SaveThePost pic.twitter.com/mDxmM4qX9g‚Äî Souad Mekhennet (@smekhennet) January 26, 2026

We're not perfect, but hundreds of us at The @washingtonpost bust our butts daily to bring you facts, expertise and context about your government & other powerful institutions, incredibly important foreign reporting and journalism you AREN'T GETTING ANYWHERE ELSE #SaveThePost‚Äî Michelle Boorstein (@mboorstein) January 26, 2026

I‚Äôve driven into hurricanes, trekked through jungles and camped on an ice sheet in sub-zero temperatures to bring you news about climate change.If you value this work, and everything else you read in @washingtonpost, help us send a message to @JeffBezos: #SavethePost pic.twitter.com/FL0FLm7vwO‚Äî Sarah Kaplan (@sarahkaplan48) January 26, 2026

It‚Äôs a dream working in Sports at The Washington Post. We take pride in our work and do our best to deliver compelling coverage you can‚Äôt find anywhere else. If that means something to you now is a good time to let everyone know. #SaveThePost‚Äî Neil Greenberg (@ngreenberg) January 26, 2026

You can't blame people for pushing to keep their jobs, but some of the people tagging onto the hashtag are arguing that Bezos has plenty of money to burn.

.@JeffBezos spent $50M on his Venice wedding. Saving a newspaper would be cheap by comparison. But now the @washingtonpost's brave foreign correspondents must launch a #SaveThePost campaign, amid rumored devastating cuts that amount to a mere rounding error to Bezos. https://t.co/XyHAuJ2Mwl‚Äî Katherine Eban (@KatherineEban) January 26, 2026

In fact, $50 million would not begin to save the Post. Bezos has spent more than that each year keeping it afloat. In 2023 the paper lost about $77million. In 2024, it reportedly lost $100 million.

The Washington Post lost around $100 million in 2024 as top journalists defected to the publication‚Äôs competitors, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday.That figure is reportedly approximately 30% greater than The Post‚Äôs losses in 2023. Advertising revenue at the publication also fell from $190 million to $174 million, WSJ wrote.These losses are reportedly compounded by The Post also losing a significant number of digital subscribers. At least 250,000 people canceled their subscriptions after The Post chose not to issue an endorsement in the 2024 presidential election, breaking a longstanding pattern, the paper reported in October.

What were the losses in 2025? We don't know but probably similar to 2024. In other words, Bezos has probably spent more than a quarter billion dollars keeping the paper going for just 3 years. And my guess is that all the metrics are going in the wrong direction. In other words, there's no end in sight to the losses. But the staff reaction to his attempt to stop the bleeding is that he's not a good steward.

A top Post reporter tells me "there's now a strong sense" across the newsroom "that neither Jeff Bezos nor Will Lewis are serious, good-faith stewards of The Washington Post." pic.twitter.com/ORtFdFmWbD‚Äî Brian Stelter (@brianstelter) January 26, 2026

Thanks for the $300 million, Jeff, but you suck!

Some of this is definitely self-inflicted. The paper was making a profit during Trump's first term because it went all in on resistance journalism. It had a staff of progressive voices that became well known on the anti-Trump left. So when there was no Trump to bash starting in 2020, readership declined. Then when Bezos demanded a bit more neutrality from the paper (canceling an endorsement of Kamala Harris) a quarter millions progressive subscribers cut them off. Simply put, the Post made itself a paper that catered to the far left and readers came to expect that. There's no going back without angering a lot of those people and losing their support. That's where things are now.

The layoffs are expected to happen in early February, so expect more on this by next week.

news.title: Pallywood Has Been Replaced by Minnewood
news.text:
If I believed the lies the Pravda Media and the Democrats were selling I, too, would be outraged about what is happening in Minneapolis. 

I don't disbelieve them merely because they are the liberal media and proven liars. (Sharp as a tack, anyone?) I disbelieve them because I have actually seen not just the "evidence" they choose to show and the pundits they allow to spew their lies; I do my best to see it all, and just as happened in Gaza, what is being presented is a carefully curated version of reality. 

üö® WTF?! CNN just aired a liberal claiming ICE is on the verge of putting people in OVENS to execute them‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying they‚Äôre putting people in ovens YET!‚Äù ü§ØHe‚Äôs openly inciting violence and CNN does nothing.ENEMY OF THE PEOPLE. pic.twitter.com/QfK4jUB9Cw‚Äî Eric Daugherty (@EricLDaugh) January 26, 2026

Or often, not reality at all. We are seeing the "fine people" hoax, the Jussie Smollett hoax, and the Covington Kids hoax repeated a thousand times. And no matter how many times these hoaxes are debunked, the next one generates the same outrage in the usual suspects because they are primed to believe the worst of anybody they dislike. 

The "bait boy" story followed an all-too-familiar pattern. Even after it was debunked, Gov. Tim Walz was still raising it late last week to paint ICE as soulless, depraved thugs. It is all part of our post-truth political environment. https://t.co/nh8oyi2c1D‚Äî Jonathan Turley (@JonathanTurley) January 26, 2026

One of the most recent and notorious of the hoaxes is the so-called "bait boy" hoax. By now you know the story: ICE detained a 5-year-old boy to use as bait to force his father to turn himself in. It is a story designed to inflame your emotions, confirm that Trump's Gestapo is just one step away from gassing the illegal immigrants, and prime you to believe that tales of ICE or Border Patrol agents casually assassinating people in the streets. 

BREAKING - ABC is now facing a potential defamation lawsuit after David Muir went on air last night and spread the lie to millions that ICE agents used a child as bait to capture his father when in reality the father abandoned his child.Every agent involved needs to sue. pic.twitter.com/AQiUtb0ktB‚Äî Right Angle News Network (@Rightanglenews) January 23, 2026

The Bait Boy story is a classic case of what I am dubbing Minnewood, the successor to Pallywood, even though the same tactics are being used throughout the country. Minneapolis is ground zero, and in a city that envies more famous ones (when I moved here, they sold mugs calling it the "Minne-apple"), it makes sense to give them a comparison to Hollywood. 

Below is my column in The Hill on the false ‚Äúbait boy‚Äù story that went viral last week, the latest concoction of the left and an enabling media. It was an all-too-familiar pattern. Even after it was debunked, Gov. Tim Walz was still raising it late last week to paint ICE as soulless, depraved thugs. It simply does not matter that it is untrue in our post-truth political environment.Here is the opinion:‚ÄúI am outraged, and you should be too.‚Äù That message from former Vice President Kamala Harris has been a virtual mantra of the Democratic Party for years. For several months, this has meant decrying the imminent death of democracy and our descent into authoritarianism. Now, it means falsely claiming that ICE ‚Äúkidnapped‚Äù or ‚Äúarrested‚Äù a five-year-old boy and used him as ‚Äúbait‚Äù to catch someone.The ‚Äúbait boy‚Äù story is actually the latest clickbait hoax in our ‚ÄúAge of Rage.‚ÄùFive years ago, Harris was expressing the same call for outrage over the false story of Border agents whipping migrants in Texas. She expressed disgust over the ‚Äúhorrible and deeply troubling‚Äù scenes reminiscent of the slave period.It quickly became a pile-on, with the media spreading the false account. Reps. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) and Ayanna Pressley (D-Mass.) described the incident as ‚Äúworse than what we witnessed in slavery‚Äù and ‚Äúwhite supremacist behavior.‚ÄùPresident Biden threw the agents under the bus, publicly expressing disgust over their conduct and promising punishment before any investigation had occurred: ‚ÄúIt was horrible what to see, as you saw ‚Äî to see people treated like they did: horses nearly running them over and people being strapped. It‚Äôs outrageous. I promise you, those people will pay.‚ÄùThe media continued to repeat the false account, even as many of us pointed out that the publicly available video showed the story was demonstrably untrue. It did not matter. It fit the narrative on the left, and the agents were left under investigation for more than a year before being cleared of the ‚Äúwhipping‚Äù charges.After the false story was exposed, the media just shrugged and went on to the next gotcha story.

The casualness with which lies are told is only possible with the complicity of the media. You probably recall the media frenzy surrounding the Covington Kids or Jussiee Smollett, but you may not recall how many days and weeks were spent pounding the false version of those stories. We are occasionally referring to the "fine people" hoax because it stuck. 

As for this new hoax, Rep. Angie Craig (D-Minn.) declared the incident to be ‚Äúthe worst of the damn worst‚Äù in a video on X. Craig, a candidate for Senate, accused federal officers of taking the boy to ‚Äúuse him to lure his father out.‚ÄùThat is false. According to reports, the father was spotted in public and fled, abandoning the boy. Like Harris, Craig reminded citizens that ‚Äúthis is a time where we should all be outraged. If this doesn‚Äôt pierce through your humanity, as a Republican member of Congress, if you can‚Äôt speak out about this, then you‚Äôve got no humanity left.‚ÄùThe key, again, is the requisite outrage. If you are not outraged, you are not human.

Big lies work. 

Another legacy media conspiracy: @washingtonpost alleges ICE used a 5-year-old kid as ‚Äúbait‚Äù to arrest his father.Not until five paragraphs into the piece do they acknowledge what really happened: the child‚Äôs father, an illegal immigrant, abandoned him when he saw ICE. pic.twitter.com/VkMnOLm4Ud‚Äî Drew Holden (@DrewHolden360) January 22, 2026

The irony of the "Bait Boy" story is that it was his FATHER who abandoned HIM, knowing full well that ICE would take care of him. Suburban moms are more afraid of ICE than actual illegal aliens because they know better. 

In this case, ICE officers were trying to detain Adrian Alexander Conejo Arias, an undocumented Ecuadorian national, when he bolted and left behind his five-year-old child, Liam Conejo Ramos.Rather than leave the child in the freezing cold on the street, the officers took the child to his home to get his mother to take him in. She refused to open the door despite agents reportedly saying that she would not be detained. They proceeded to take the boy to McDonald‚Äôs, play his favorite music, and take care of him. He was never arrested. They also did not send him into detention. According to ICE, his father asked for the boy to be allowed to stay with him at a detention facility, and ICE agreed.

But none of that matters in the propaganda war. Repeat "Gestapo" enough, and the outrage meter is pegged. People see what they want to see, and they want to be angry at Bad Orange Man and MAGA. Defund the Police has turned into Defund ICE, and the Democrats are talking about shutting down the government to defund ICE. 

Probably one of the most insane sentences ever published in the @nytimes.And that's saying something. pic.twitter.com/iYZzU2oGUT‚Äî Yehuda Teitelbaum (@chalavyishmael) January 25, 2026

Ana Navarro lies and says government doesn‚Äôt lie except this one.Give us a break.She then regurgitates the hoax about the 5-year-old who was actually abandoned by her dad (an illegal) but who she says ICE detained to use as bait.Navarro always lies.pic.twitter.com/GHkeTyt9at‚Äî Paul A. Szypula üá∫üá∏ (@Bubblebathgirl) January 26, 2026

The whole point of the assaults on ICE is to generate clickbait. Clips taken out of context that make ICE look bad, happily spread by a media that wants the story. They don't challenge lies and are willing to amplify them if they fit The Narrative‚Ñ¢.

This was only from YESTERDAY and it did not age well.Nekima Armstrong LIED to CNN and said the mob group participated in the church service they disrupted.Now she's arrested.Mess around and find out what happens. pic.twitter.com/XObfOCXDgj‚Äî DeVory Darkins (@devorydarkins) January 22, 2026

A bald-faced lie told, and the response? "I am not going to dispute your saying what happened."

Have you ever heard a reporter not take every chance to challenge a Republican? But a communist agitator‚Äîspew whatever lie you like on our airwaves. 

This is sick! This is how lies start! I never trust things I read/watch these days pic.twitter.com/bu8YpJJKze‚Äî Anticommie (@QueenAnticommie) January 19, 2026

We see hoaxes every day, yet somehow the credibility of the hoaxers is never challenged. That's because the media, for the most part, likes the hoaxes. 

Tim Walz seems like a unique leader in that during a crisis he does something so insane that he gets yelled at by the Holocaust Museum https://t.co/81A0gcsKa8‚Äî Carl Paulus (@CarlPaulus) January 26, 2026

It's easy to tell lies when nobody calls you out on it. Even easier when the media is in on it with you. 

For those not seeing it, I got you pic.twitter.com/r3JI4RUVe2‚Äî Cameron Sagason (@CameronSagason) January 25, 2026
