news.title: Why the shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis is so significant ‚Äì expert Q&A
news.text:
Federal immigration agents in the city of Minneapolis are accused of having wrestled a 37-year-old intensive care nurse called Alex Pretti to the ground and then shooting him dead. The killing took place just over a mile from where another American citizen, Renee Good, was allegedly fatally shot by federal agents weeks earlier.

The latest incident prompted angry protests from people in Minneapolis who want the immigration enforcement operation in their city to end. We spoke to Mark Shanahan, an associate professor of political engagement at the University of Surrey, to address several key issues.

Why has sending in federal immigration agents caused such trouble in Minnesota?

Since returning to the White House in January 2025, the national guard has been deployed to several US cities to quell what have generally been Donald Trump-inflated crises, with illegal migration among the most prominent. However, in December, the Supreme Court ruled that Trump did not have authority for such deployments. 

So, since then we have seen federal agents with US Customs and Border Protection and Immigration and Customs Enforcement taking the battle largely to minorities in cities with Democratic party leadership as part of the president‚Äôs violent attack on illegal immigration, a situation he has described as ‚Äúthe greatest invasion in history‚Äù. 

Minneapolis is a Democrat-run city in a Democrat-led state. The governor is Tim Walz who ran for vice-president on the Kamala Harris ticket against Trump in the 2024 election. Walz has faced allegations, which he denies, of overlooking alleged widespread fraud in the financing of public safety net programmes, supposedly involving segments of the Somali-American community. 

While most of these allegations have been refuted, they gave Trump reason to send in federal agents. This has ramped up tensions between state officials and the administration, causing brutal and unnecessary deaths in the community and pitting ordinary Minnesotans against federal government officials. 

How does the situation in Minnesota reflect the second amendment right to bear arms?

It‚Äôs a reversal of virtually all of the second amendment debates that have been seen in recent years. The second amendment was introduced to the US constitution in 1791 through the Bill of Rights due to a deep mistrust of centralised military power and a desire to ensure that the newly formed federal government could not disarm the populace. 

The founding fathers envisaged a ‚Äúnatural right of resistance and self-preservation‚Äù. Trump‚Äôs actions in sending in armed federal agents to conduct enforcement operations in various states appear to fulfil the founding fathers‚Äô concerns. 

The agents are trampling all over not only citizens‚Äô second amendment right to bear arms (officials seemingly connected Pretti‚Äôs killing to him carrying a weapon) but also their first amendment right to freedom of assembly.

 Read more:
 Shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis has put America's gun lobby at odds with the White House

How have the fatal shootings affected Trump‚Äôs popularity?

Trump‚Äôs popularity is on the decline. His failure to deliver on the economic promises outlined in his election campaign, scatter-gun approach to international relations and the widening gulf between rhetoric and achievement have all damaged his standing in the polls. 

In a CNN poll published on January 16, almost six in ten respondents described Trump‚Äôs first year back in office as a failure with the president focused on the wrong priorities. 

And what support he does have is ebbing rapidly as federal immigration agents appear out of control, targeting many more documented citizens than illegal migrants, spreading fear and operating as if they are above the law. 

With what looks like high levels of gaslighting coming from Homeland Security officials, voters are turning against the increasing autocracy of this administration, believing in the evidence widespread across the media rather than highly contentious statements from Trump‚Äôs lieutenants. 

Is it unusual for former presidents to speak out the way Barack Obama and Bill Clinton have?

It certainly is. There is a longstanding tradition in the US of, and implicit agreement among, former presidents to avoid public criticism of the incumbent. Such reticence to speak is generally a sign of respect for the office and an acknowledgement of the unique and difficult challenges of the presidency. 

But Trump 2.0 is no normal presidency. The 47th president‚Äôs style is both combative and retributive, and there seems to be an increasing feeling of it being out of step with the desires and best interest of the country he leads. 

Trump‚Äôs march to autocracy creates crises where he regards himself as the hero the country needs to overcome its ills. His predecessors take a different view. 

Whether it‚Äôs Obama calling out the assault on core American values or Clinton‚Äôs condemnation of the ‚Äúhorrible scenes‚Äù in Minneapolis as ‚Äúunacceptable‚Äù and avoidable, Democrat past presidents have not held back. Notably, the only living previous Republican president, George W. Bush, has so far kept his own counsel. 

What can be done to prevent further violence?

Most simply, Trump could end the deployment of federal immigration agents to Minneapolis and refrain from similar actions in the future. He is clearly looking for an off-ramp and sending his ‚Äúborder czar‚Äù, Tom Homan, to Minneapolis to direct operations could be the first step to de-escalation. But Trump abhors being called out as wrong and, at least beyond Minneapolis, is far more likely to double down on the immigration enforcement activities. 

Realistically, the most likely de-escalator is Congress showing some teeth and refusing to fund further federal immigration enforcement activity. Democrats could force another government shutdown over the issue, and need just a handful of Republicans to flip in order to refuse to sanction a 2026 budget for the Department of Homeland Security. 

At a public level, the greater the scrutiny of immigration enforcement agencies, the closer the fact-checking of official statements and the more cohesive the opposition to Trump‚Äôs deportation policy, the greater the chance of effectively opposing it. 

It is midterm year ‚Äì and the greater the public pressure, the more likely Republican legislators are to cleave away from the Trump line. While he currently controls the levers of power, that control remains fragile. Even Trump may soon realise that overt, violent, coercive autocracy is not a vote winner.
news.summary: Alex Pretti‚Äôs death has been met with global outrage. Mark Shanahan addresses the key issues and considers what it means for Trump.
news.author: Associate Professor of Political Engagement,Mark Shanahan,University of Surrey

news.title: The net worth you need to be considered poor, middle-class and wealthy in America
news.text:
A financial analyst has determined the precise points at which an American citizen‚Äôs net worth might be considered poor, middle-class or wealthy using the latest data from the Federal Reserve Board‚Äôs Survey of Consumer Finances.

Economics expert and author Geoff Schmidt has told Benzinga that such figures, calculated by subtracting liabilities from assets, vary dramatically across the country, but, broadly speaking, a U.S. household with a net worth of approximately $20,856 or less might be categorised as poor. 

Anyone to whom that applies is unlikely to own their own home and is likely to have to commit their capital to essentials like groceries, rent and utility bills.

A middle-class household, by contrast, has an average net worth of $193,000. Such a family unit would typically have home equity, savings, and a 401(k) account.

A well-off family, according to the Federal Reserve benchmarks, would have a net worth of around $1.6 million ‚Äì enough to have disposable income available for family trips, college funds, and regular charitable donations.

To be considered wealthy, a household‚Äôs net worth would be closer to $3.8 million ‚Äì the sort of money that might open up the possibility of owning multiple properties.

Finally, those in the top one percent are likely to have a wealth of $11.6 million or more and enjoy lives of obvious freedom and luxury.

Schmidt‚Äôs conclusions, by his own admission, are slightly out of step with the findings of Schwab‚Äôs 2024 Modern Wealth Survey, which found that a majority of Americans considered an average net worth of $778,000 to mean ‚Äúfinancially comfortable,‚Äù $2.5 million sufficient to signify wealth, and $11 million an indicator of elite wealth. 

The current average annual wage in the United States is $82,933, according to the OECD, which ranks it fourth in the world, behind only Luxembourg, Iceland, and Switzerland, and well ahead of Canada ($69,417) and the U.K. ($63,691).

Nevertheless, many Americans still feel uneasy about the state of the economy and want President Donald Trump to do more to address the affordability crisis, according to the latest polls.

The economy remains the primary concern for many, with 55 percent in a CNN/SSRS survey earlier this month saying they believe Trump‚Äôs policies during his first year back in office had only made matters worse, compared to 32 percent arguing they had made an improvement, a damning verdict on his controversial reciprocal tariffs program, through which he is attempting to reset the terms of international trade. 

A huge 64 percent said the president has not done enough to bring down the cost of living, a key reason many people voted for him over former Vice President Kamala Harris in November 2024, with even 42 percent of Republicans saying more needs to be done to lower the price of everyday goods.

With one eye on November‚Äôs midterms, the president will hope to correct that perception Tuesday when he follows up his December trip to Pennsylvania to address the economy with a visit to Des Moines, Iowa, to address the same theme.

Trump‚Äôs previous appearance at a casino in Mount Pocono saw him veer off script and, rather than offer reassurances, lash out at Democrats for pushing an ‚Äúaffordability hoax,‚Äù telling his audience in the Keystone State that ‚Äúprices are way down‚Äù and that they had nothing to worry about. 

The president can expect more pressure on the issue, given that he repeatedly promised voters during the presidential election that he would usher in a new ‚Äúgolden age,‚Äù revitalize manufacturing, and create untold numbers of jobs, meaning they would soon have more money than they knew what to do with, a dream yet to be realized.
news.summary: An average net worth of $20,856 would be categorised as poor, whereas one of $3.8 million signifies wealth, a financial expert has said
news.author: Joe Sommerlad

news.title: Mid-Day Digest
news.text:
THE FOUNDATION

‚ÄúNo compact among men ‚Ä¶ can be pronounced everlasting and inviolable, and if I may so express myself, that no Wall of words, that no mound of parchment can be so formed as to stand against the sweeping torrent of boundless ambition on the one side, aided by the sapping current of corrupted morals on the other.‚Äù ‚ÄîGeorge Washington (1789)

IN TODAY‚ÄôS DIGEST

Executive News Summary
Featured Analysis: Armed Subversive Shot in Minneapolis
More Analysis
Best of Right Opinion
Best of Videos

Today‚Äôs Meme

EXECUTIVE NEWS SUMMARY

The Editors

Winter storm leaves a mark: An unusually large and powerful winter storm has nearly finished dumping a colossal amount of snow and ice on the U.S. after it traveled from Arizona to Maine. Over three-quarters of a million Americans experienced power outages, with many regions warning that turning the lights back on will be a slow process. Making these long power outages even worse, reinforcing shots of bitterly cold Arctic air are forecast to move over the eastern half of the U.S. through at least next week. Nine deaths have been attributed to the storm so far ‚Äî seven in the South, one in Kansas, and one in Massachusetts. Southern states saw freezing rain and ice that brought down trees and power lines, while northern states saw over 18 inches of snow.
Comer suggests leaving Minnesota to its fate: With the shooting death of anti-ICE agitator Alex Pretti by ICE agents over the weekend in Minneapolis, which has served to fuel even more anti-ICE sentiments, House Oversight Committee Chair James Comer suggested that the Trump administration pull back on immigration enforcement in Minnesota. ‚ÄúIf I were President Trump, I would almost think about, OK, if the mayor and the governor are going to put our ICE officials in harm‚Äôs way and there‚Äôs a chance of losing more, you know, innocent lives or whatever, then maybe go to another city and let the people of Minneapolis decide, ‚ÄòDo we want to continue to have all of these illegals? Are we going to allow our governor, attorney general, and mayor to get away with this?‚Äô‚Äù A number of Republican lawmakers are also calling for a full investigation into Pretti‚Äôs death.
Dems gear up for another shutdown over ICE: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer is signaling that the budget will not be passed by the deadline this Friday, and another shutdown may be looming. Congress has been passing the budget in separate appropriations bills this month rather than via the titanic omnibus bills seen too often in recent years, but DHS funding is unlikely to make it past Senate Democrats. Senators Schumer, Catherine Cortez Masto, and Jack Reed have suggested dropping the DHS bill and passing the remaining five bills for other government departments. Others have suggested reworking the DHS bill, although time is limited for that with the deadline looming and the Senate out of session today due to inclement weather. Schumer‚Äôs grandstanding comes in response to the deaths of two leftist agitators who were killed as they impeded ongoing law enforcement operations.
Don Lemon should be arrested: On Saturday, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit declined the DOJ‚Äôs request to overturn a Minnesota magistrate judge‚Äôs refusal to approve arrest warrants for five anti-ICE agitators who stormed and disrupted a St. Paul, Minnesota, church‚Äôs worship service. Among the individuals the DOJ sought to arrest was former CNN personality Don Lemon. While the Eighth Circuit Court refused to overturn the judge, it concluded that the DOJ met the probable cause standard for charging Lemon and the other agitators. Lemon, meanwhile, sought to frame himself as completely innocent and insisted that the Trump administration would ‚Äúgo around a judge‚Äù in its efforts to prosecute him. Lemon continued to paint himself as not one of the agitators, despite participating in and defending the action as a legitimate protest.
Virginia Dems push for highest income tax in nation: California currently imposes the highest income tax in the nation, but may not much longer if Democrats in Virginia get their way. Democrat legislators in the Commonwealth introduced legislation that would effectively increase Virginia‚Äôs top income tax rate to 13.8%. These lawmakers are couching the tax hike as making ‚Äúmillionaires pay their fair share of taxes.‚Äù They want to increase the state government‚Äôs annual revenue by $1 billion to fund a range of increases in welfare-related services, including education, housing, and public services. The irony is that new Democrat Gov. Abigail Spanberger focused her campaign on making Virginia affordable. This legislation would produce the exact opposite, but Spanberger has proven that her campaign messaging was intended to deceive, not inform voters of her intentions.
Canada backs down on China deal: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney visited China last week and said the country would embrace a partnership with that nation for the new world order. During Carney‚Äôs visit, the two countries proposed a deal to lower tariffs on Chinese EVs and Canadian agricultural products. Carney went so far as to blast the use of tariffs in a speech to the World Economic Forum, a comment that was likely directed at the U.S. president. Donald Trump said he would not allow Canada to serve as ‚Äúa ‚ÄòDrop Off Port‚Äô for China‚Äù to send products into the U.S. He then threatened to impose a 100% tariff on Canadian products if Canada signed the proposed deal with China. Since then, Carney has backed off the deal, saying his country has no plans to pursue it.
Secret weapon against Venezuela? ‚ÄúThe Discombobulator. I‚Äôm not allowed to talk about it,‚Äù said President Trump right before he revealed that it had been used in the extraction of Nicol√°s Maduro from Venezuela. Both Trump and Venezuelan sources have attested to the use of a secret weapon that neutralized Venezuelan air defenses, communications, and command systems before U.S. helicopters entered Caracas. ‚ÄúThey never got their rockets off. They pressed buttons, and nothing worked,‚Äù Trump remarked. The details of the weapon remain classified, but several Venezuelan witnesses on the ground confirmed that something ‚Äúlike a very intense sound wave‚Äù was launched that shut down all their foreign-supplied radar and defense systems, incapacitating their ability to respond. The Trump-dubbed ‚Äúdiscombobulator‚Äù did its job to bring about the detention of Maduro, demonstrating American dominance.
Orwellian ‚Äúkill switch‚Äù speeds ahead: Sometimes when Congress is trying to accomplish big things, like fund the Departments of War, Housing and Urban Development, Transportation, and Health and Human Services, smaller things can slip through the cracks. But when that ‚Äúsmaller thing‚Äù is a kill switch that will automatically shut off an American‚Äôs car, voters understandably get angry. Rep. Thomas Massie proposed an amendment to be added to the funding bill that would counter a Biden-era requirement to develop a kill switch in cars aimed at stopping drunk driving. Massie‚Äôs amendment failed when 76 Republicans voted with Democrats against it. Opponents of the kill switch have rightly called it Orwellian; the pressure will be on for Republicans to propose clean legislation to kill the kill switch.
Mullahs have killed more than 30,000 protesters: The total number of Iranian protesters slain in the Islamic government‚Äôs crackdown on widespread protests across the country since December 28 has been difficult to ascertain. The official state media has put the total killed at just over 3,000, while the U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency has placed the estimate at just under 5,000. Data from Iranian doctors puts the total at 16,500. However, a recent report from two senior Iranian Ministry of Health officials estimates the number to be more than 30,000. And that number came in just two days ‚Äî January 8 and 9. Those killed were primarily by gunshot wounds, which would be in line with the Iranian regime‚Äôs use of military forces to quell the protests. If these numbers are accurate, it would represent the single largest mass killing by a government‚Äôs forces against its own people in the modern era.

Trump sending border czar Tom Homan to Minnesota (NewsNation)
DHS officials debunk viral claims ICE used five-year-old boy as ‚Äúbait‚Äù (NY Post)
IDF recovers body of final hostage Ran Gvili (Jerusalem Post)
Columbia University picks new president after scrutiny over mishandling campus protests (NY Post)

The Executive News Summary is compiled daily by Jordan Candler, Thomas Gallatin, Sterling Henry, and Sophie Starkova. For the archive, click here.

Comment | Share

FEATURED ANALYSIS

Armed Subversive Shot in Minneapolis

Douglas Andrews

First things first: We here in our shop roundly reject the use of deadly force against peaceful protesters exercising their First Amendment rights. Of course, nothing like that has happened in the sanctuary state of Minnesota or anywhere else, and we commend our law enforcement officers for their remarkable restraint amid untold thousands of tension-filled encounters with not-so-peaceful provocateurs.

And because of this, we can say unequivocally: Had Renee Good and Alex Pretti been peaceful protesters rather than violent agitators obstructing federal law enforcement operations, they‚Äôd be alive today. Full stop.

The video of the Pretti shooting is grim, as shootings always are.

As The Wall Street Journal reports, ‚ÄúIn the hours after the shooting, the Department of Homeland Security alleged that Pretti ‚Äòviolently resisted‚Äô disarmament until officers fired ‚Äòdefensive shots.‚Äô But bystander footage ‚Ä¶ contradicts that version of events. The footage appears to show a federal officer pulling a handgun away from Pretti. Less than a second later, an agent fires several rounds.‚Äù

That‚Äôs a troubling assessment, to be sure, and it appears that DHS Secretary Kristi Noem got a bit out over her skis in her initial explanation of events. But prudent people, from President Donald Trump all the way down, are right to refrain from rendering a judgment until all the facts are in, all the officers involved have been interviewed, and all the video footage has been thoroughly reviewed.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre looking, we‚Äôre reviewing everything and will come out with a determination,‚Äù said the president yesterday during a five-minute phone interview with the Journal. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt like any shooting. But I don‚Äôt like it when somebody goes into a protest, and he‚Äôs got a very powerful, fully loaded gun with two magazines loaded up with bullets also. That doesn‚Äôt play good either.‚Äù

Minnesota is a right-to-carry state, and Pretti was indeed carrying ‚Äî which he had every right to do. But one has to question the wisdom of wading into a tense law enforcement operation with a loaded weapon if your intent is merely to peacefully protest. In any case, it‚Äôs rather rich to see all these leftists suddenly finding their religion on Second Amendment rights.

As our Mark Alexander, himself a former law enforcement officer, notes, ‚ÄúIn a confrontation with police, there is no obligation that they stop and ask about your carry permit. That‚Äôs a red herring. And it‚Äôs not clear whether, when resisting arrest, Pretti, at some point, reached for his weapon.‚Äù

If only Minnesota‚Äôs state and local law enforcement officials were working with their federal brothers rather than against them. To this point, President Trump took to ALL CAPS to say, ‚ÄúLET OUR ICE PATRIOTS DO THEIR JOB!‚Äù while adding that failed Governor Tim Walz and insurrectionist Mayor Jacob Frey ‚Äúare inciting Insurrection, with their pompous, dangerous, and arrogant rhetoric!‚Äù

In addition, Trump took to Truth Social to announce that he‚Äôs sending Border Czar Tom Homan to Minnesota. ‚ÄúHe has not been involved in that area,‚Äù said Trump, ‚Äúbut knows and likes many of the people there. Tom is tough but fair, and will report directly to me.‚Äù Homan, as you‚Äôll recall, is the career law-enforcement professional who was presented with the nation‚Äôs highest civil service award by none other than Barack Obama ‚Äî and then promptly branded a Nazi when he answered Donald Trump‚Äôs call to service.

Speaking of Nazis, I give you Governor Walz, who disgracefully demagogued over the weekend, ‚ÄúWe have got children in Minnesota hiding in their houses afraid to go outside. Many of us grew up reading that story of Anne Frank. Somebody‚Äôs gonna write that children‚Äôs story about Minnesota.‚Äù

If only somebody would write a children‚Äôs story about the need for a civil society to enforce its laws. And about the difference between peaceful protest and violent insurrection.

MORE ANALYSIS

Nate Jackson: Unpacking the Left‚Äôs Anti-ICE Strategy ‚Äî Clearly, leftist agitators are training and organizing to incite exactly the kinds of hostilities that are getting people killed. Why?
Thomas Gallatin: Dropping Crime Rate Vindicates Trump ‚Äî Over the last year, the homicide rate has dropped by 21% across the country, demonstrating that simply enforcing the nation‚Äôs laws is benefiting everyone.
Emmy Griffin: A Precarious TikTok Deal ‚Äî The great negotiator, Donald Trump, has facilitated a long-overdue deal, but there‚Äôs still concern that the Chinese retain the ability to spy on Americans.

Roger Helle: In Their Own Words ‚Äî We‚Äôve become used to lying, but there is a spiritual gift in the Word of God that we‚Äôve overlooked. It‚Äôs called ‚Äúdiscernment.‚Äù

Fact-Check: False

False Equivalence

‚ÄúIt is really damning when we think about the degree to which mass-media outlets reported on Joe Biden. ‚Ä¶ Yet we are seeing behavior from Donald Trump that is increasingly erratic and alarming and everyone‚Äôs pretending that this is normal.‚Äù ‚ÄîRep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY)

The BIG Lies

‚ÄúLiam Ramos is just a baby. He should be at home with his family, not used as bait by ICE and held in a Texas detention center.‚Äù ‚Äîformer Vice President Kamala Harris

Re: The Left

‚ÄúThe Mayor and the Governor are inciting Insurrection, with their pompous, dangerous, and arrogant rhetoric! Instead, these sanctimonious political fools should be looking for the Billions of Dollars that has been stolen from the people of Minnesota, and the United States of America. LET OUR ICE PATRIOTS DO THEIR JOB!‚Äù ‚ÄîPresident Donald Trump after the latest fatal confrontation with police in Minneapolis

‚ÄúOne has to ask, what is all this hullabaloo going on in Minneapolis? Simple, it is about deranged people who do not understand the law, and are willfully breaking the law, and insidiously defending those who have broken the law.‚Äù ‚ÄîAllen West

‚ÄúJoe Biden and Kamala Harris opened the border, creating a humanitarian crisis, and now leftists say the real problem is cleaning up that mess.‚Äù ‚ÄîNate Jackson

‚ÄúWhen I fret that the Trump administration may be overplaying its hand in dealing with narco-terrorists, I am reminded we are in this position because of Biden, a man the very Democrats who demand I denounce Trump gave cover to, a pass to and pretended he had no problems.‚Äù ‚ÄîErick Erickson

European Weakness

‚ÄúJust last year, here in Davos, I ended my speech with the words, ‚ÄòEurope needs to know how to defend itself.‚Äô A year has passed, and nothing has changed.‚Äù ‚ÄîUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky

For the Record

‚ÄúBased upon a very productive meeting that I have had with the Secretary General of NATO, Mark Rutte, we have formed the framework of a future deal with respect to Greenland and, in fact, the entire Arctic Region. This solution, if consummated, will be a great one for the United States of America, and all NATO Nations.‚Äù ‚ÄîDonald Trump

The Tide Is Turning

‚ÄúIn essence, [JPMorgan Chase] debanked plaintiff‚Äôs accounts because it believed that the political tide at the moment favored doing so. JPMC‚Äôs reckless decision is leading a growing trend by financial institutions in the United States of America to cut off a consumer‚Äôs access to banking services if their political views contradict with those of the financial institution.‚Äù ‚Äîlegal complaint in the lawsuit between Donald Trump and JPMorgan Chase bank

‚ÄúIn the ancient pagan world, discarding children was routine. From the skeletons in brothels to the child sacrifice of the Mayans, the mark of barbarism is that we treat babies like inconveniences to be discarded rather than the blessings to cherish that they are. ‚Ä¶ The March for Life ‚Ä¶ is about whether we will remain a civilization under God or we whether we ultimately return to the paganism that dominated the past.‚Äù ‚ÄîVice President JD Vance

Roasting Gavin, Again

‚ÄúI think [Gavin Newsom] may be in over his hairdo. And being on the national stage is very different than being governor of California with no signature achievements. But to say strange things like, ‚ÄòPresident Trump is a Tyrannosaurus rex‚Äô ‚Äî what the [heck] does that mean? I could say, ‚ÄòGavin Newsom is a Brontosaurus with a brain the size of a walnut.‚Äô‚Äù ‚ÄîTreasury Secretary Scott Bessent

Belly Laugh of the Day

news.title: Democratic state Senate hopefuls debate: Will geography matter this election?
news.text:
SAGINAW, MI ‚Äî Can a candidate with Saginaw roots win an election for a seat that also represents their Bay City and Midland neighbors?

That‚Äôs a question that may receive an answer on Tuesday, Feb. 3, when voters cast ballots in the primary phase of the special election that will determine who fills the 35th District state Senate seat vacated by Kristen McDonald Rivet 12 months ago.

Statistically, there‚Äôs a decent chance a Saginaw County-based Democratic candidate‚Äôs name will appear on the ballot during the general election phase of the voting in May. After all, of the Democratic primary field‚Äôs six candidates, five reside in Saginaw County: Brandell Adams, Martin Blank, Chedrick Greene, Pamela Pugh and Serenity Hope Salak.

One candidate, William Morrone, hails from Bay County.

The state Senate district encompasses parts of Bay, Midland and Saginaw counties, including their namesake cities that also serve as their highest-density population centers.

Since its boundaries were drawn during a 2021 statewide redistricting process, the 35th District‚Äôs voters have only elected one person: Rivet, a Democrat from Bay City. 

The district maintains overlapping interests and industries, but each of its three counties possess distinct qualities and political leanings, as evidenced by the way its residents tend to vote in elections.

Perhaps one of the measuring tools to best gauge the state of those leanings involves examining how each county has voted in presidential elections.

All three counties favored Republican Donald Trump in the 2024 election. But the margins of victory in each community revealed Saginaw County was the most enthusiastic for the Democratic opponent, Kamala Harris. There, 47.7% of voters favored Harris. In both Bay and Midland counties, meanwhile, the Democrat received about 6 percentage points fewer votes than in Saginaw County.

The margins have changed over the generations, but those political party preferences aren‚Äôt new. Midland County has not voted for a Democrat for president since 1964 and Bay County has favored sending a Republican to the White House since 2016. Before Trump, Saginaw County had not voted for a GOP presidential candidate since 1984.

So, will it be a challenge for a Democrat from a lighter-red county such as Saginaw County to win over swing voters in neighboring communities that traditionally lean further to the conservative right? Will that even matter in the primary phase of a special election?

MLive posed these questions to all six Democratic hopefuls. 

Of the four candidates who responded, three acknowledged the communities‚Äô differences but stated the district as a whole carries common needs that their respective campaigns‚Äô policy ideas would answer. Another candidate ‚Äî Morrone, the lone hopeful from outside Saginaw County ‚Äî said his Bay County roots in part position him best to understand the needs of all three counties.

Pride, pain, opportunity

One factor that could help the candidates increase their name recognition and communicate their messages to constituents across the district: money.

Campaign finance filings published last week on the Michigan Secretary of State finance disclosure webpage showed Greene reported more than double the amount of contributions than the next-closest Democrat, Pugh. In fact, Greene‚Äôs campaign contributions and expenditures were larger than anyone in the candidate field, including the four Republicans in the race.

The state filings showed Greene‚Äôs campaign contributions totaled $263,752.85, while his expenditures totaled $222,598.76.

By comparison, the reports showed Pugh‚Äôs campaign contributions totaled $120,629.04 with expenditures of $99,520.75. No other Democrat reported contributions larger than $18,585.

The Democratic candidates who responded to MLive said their ability to connect with the district constituents‚Äô needs will determine their success in courting votes.

Greene in a statement said he and his campaign team have listened to constituents in an effort ‚Äúto know the points of pride, pain and opportunity‚Äù in each of the district‚Äôs distinct communities.

Still, he said, there are shared priorities in each county that allow his campaign to offer solutions that would benefit the entire district.

‚ÄúThe issues that consistently rise to the top across our Great Lakes Bay Region are affordability, safety and our freedoms,‚Äù said Greene, a Saginaw firefighter who earned the endorsement of Rivet.

Pugh, an elected member of the Michigan State Board of Education with a history of courting and receiving votes from constituents outside of her home county, in a statement said she views District 35 as sharing in ‚Äúcore beliefs, values and concerns.‚Äù

‚ÄúAcross Saginaw, Bay, and Midland, voters are focused on the same priorities: good-paying jobs; rising cost burdens driven by policy choices that favor corporate interests while leaving working families behind; affordable housing and childcare; strong public schools; reliable infrastructure; and access to health care,‚Äù she said.

Adams, who also serves as chairman of the Saginaw County Democratic Party, in a statement said his campaign was committed to reaching voters in all corners of District 35.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve listened to (constituents‚Äô) stories from rural communities to urban neighborhoods, and I know that when everyone participates, we‚Äôll get a senator with a real mandate to deliver results,‚Äù Adams said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why my team and I are knocking on doors, making calls, and listening everywhere: to ensure (the constituency‚Äôs) voice strengthens mine in Lansing.‚Äù

Standing in the gap

Morrone in a statement said Saginaw and Midland counties‚Äô voters share the fewest commonalities among people in the 35th District‚Äôs communities.

‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt see a candidate from Saginaw being able to understand and demonstrate the ability to work with Saginaw, Midland and Bay City jobs, housing, politics and health care,‚Äù said Morrone, who works as chief medical examiner in Bay County. 

Because of his background in Bay County, the Democrat said he was the candidate best positioned to understand voters in the two neighboring counties.

He said ‚Äúpurple‚Äù Bay City was ‚Äústanding in the gap‚Äù between ‚Äúred‚Äù Midland and ‚Äúblue‚Äù Saginaw.

‚ÄúSaginaw voters cannot identify or understand the Midland area; Midland culture and resources are outside of the Saginaw focus,‚Äù Morrone said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the moderate in the middle. Bay City people can appeal to Midland voters. Bay City people can appeal to Saginaw voters.‚Äù

Morrone said his career has involved work in Midland and Saginaw as well, providing him a perspective of both communities.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen 400,000 patients in 20 years, and I‚Äôve seen these counties through their eyes,‚Äù Morrone said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs an advantage. No other candidate can claim it.‚Äù

Other candidates disagreed Morrone was the lone hopeful able to relate to the district in its entirety.

‚ÄúIn our diverse district spanning three unique counties and diverse communities, I‚Äôm personally committed to reaching every single voter ‚Äî not just because it builds trust and drives turnout, but because no community should be left out of the conversation that shapes our collective future," Adams said.

Pugh said her professional experience in public service across the region and state allows her to appeal to voters of all types of backgrounds. She served as chief public health advisor to Flint during the administration of former Mayor Karen Weaver and has remained a member of the State Board of Education since 2014.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve worked alongside scientists, educators, public-health professionals, local leaders, and community organizations throughout Saginaw, Bay, and Midland counties for years,‚Äù Pugh said. ‚ÄúI have deep relationships across the district, and my family has been engaged in youth STEAM education for nearly four decades.‚Äù

Greene said his campaign‚Äôs messaging to the district‚Äôs constituents does not vary depending on the community.

‚ÄúMy message focus ‚Äî how I‚Äôm the right leader for this moment and district to stand up to MAGA extremists to improve affordability through lower costs and better-paying jobs, keep our kids and communities safe, and defend our freedoms and democracy ‚Äî is the same whether I am at a candidate forum in Bay, a meet and greet in Midland, or talking with union members in Saginaw,‚Äù Greene said.

The campaign of Salak, who worked as an eligibility specialist at the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services, declined to respond to questions from MLive.

The campaign of Blank, a trauma surgeon at Covenant HealthCare in Saginaw, did not respond to messages from MLive.

The winner of the February Democratic primary election will face the victor in the GOP primary that same day. Voters then will choose between the Democratic and Republican winners in the Tuesday, May 5, special election, sending the victor to Lansing.

The Republican candidates are Jason Tunney, Chadwick Twillman, Christian Velasquez and Andrew Wendt.
news.summary: Five of six Democratic candidates live in Saginaw County while competing for District 35, which also spans parts of the deeper-red counties of Bay and Midland.
news.author: Justin Engel

news.title: Victor Joecks: Can the Vances Make It Cool to Have Kids?
news.text:
Vice President J.D. Vance is putting his own spin on MAGA ‚Äî Make America Grow Again.

Vance and Second Lady Usha Vance recently announced that she is pregnant. Their fourth child, a boy, is due in June. Usha isn‚Äôt the only woman connected to the White House who is expecting. Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt and Katie Miller, wife of Deputy Chief of Staff Stephen Miller, are both pregnant, too.

Talk about leading by example. This baby boom fits perfectly with the vision J.D. Vance articulated at last year‚Äôs March for Life.

‚ÄúI want more babies in the United States of America,‚Äù Vance said. ‚ÄúI want more happy children in our country, and I want beautiful young men and women who are eager to welcome them into the world and eager to raise them.‚Äù

Sadly, an increasing number of people aren‚Äôt interested. A recent New York Times poll found that among childless 18-to-29-year-olds, just 57% said they would like children in the future.

Among all childless women, the rate was 32%, while among men it was 43%. There‚Äôs a stark partisan divide here, too. Just 25% of former Vice President Kamala Harris voters said they wanted kids. Among President Donald Trump voters, it was 43%. These percentages are lower because the sample includes those aged 45 and older.

It‚Äôs unsurprising then that America‚Äôs fertility rate hit a record low in 2024. The fertility rate has been below replacement level for more than 15 years. This baby bust will have significant negative consequences in the future.

The problem is worse in other countries, especially in Asia. Last year, China had the same number of births as in around 1738, Reuters reported. Its population is now shrinking. South Korea‚Äôs anemic fertility rate is on pace to cut the country‚Äôs population in half within 60 years.

Governments around the world have tried in vain to reverse this trend. Their main strategy has been throwing money at it, which hasn‚Äôt worked. That‚Äôs because raising a child requires far more work and commitment than a full-time job. Even payments worth thousands of dollars do little to change that calculus.

Think of the irony. Modern society put a man on the moon, but can‚Äôt reproduce itself as well as civilizations that used stone tools. Here are some reasons why.

First, the sexual revolution disconnected sex from marriage and reproduction. Young men have always wanted to have sex. Throughout human history, societies steered that desire toward marriage, a foundational pillar of civilization. This benefitted societies by channeling the strength and competitiveness of young men into something productive ‚Äî providing for their families. It also led to more babies.

Today, teenagers can readily view pornography on their phones. Sex isn‚Äôt saved for marriage, but treated as a recreational activity. If that leads to pregnancy, the next step isn‚Äôt for a man to marry his girlfriend, but to drive her to an abortion clinic.

America slaughters 1 million preborn babies annually. Experts then wonder why the birth rate is so low.

Next, modern feminism told women to find fulfillment in climbing the corporate ladder, not motherhood. That‚Äôs the path to misery. As the Institute for Family Studies has detailed, marriage and children bring parents greater connection and happiness.

Finally, popular culture doesn‚Äôt promote marriage and motherhood. Social media glamorizes vacation selfies, not comforting a crying baby three times in one night. Mothers, especially moms of large families, should be treated like societal rock stars.

What‚Äôs needed isn‚Äôt just better laws, but a change in personal priorities. People need to believe the truth.

For a married couple, having kids is one of the most meaningful and rewarding things anyone could ever do. The Vance family is living proof of that.

news.title: Stunning twist of fate that saw Brittany leave Patrick Mahomes weeks after he was drafted by the Chiefs...
news.text:
Of all places, it was an airport in Iceland where his future with the Kansas City Chiefs, for a moment at least, may have felt overwhelming for Patrick Mahomes. 

It was July 2017, three months after being drafted by the team. He had moved from Texas to Missouri and dived head first into Andy Reid's playbook, which he had packed into his suitcase. Figure that out, and he would hold the keys to the rest of his career as an NFL quarterback.

But he was in Iceland for his girlfriend, childhood sweetheart Brittany. In a remarkable twist of fate, she was moving overseas weeks after the Chiefs traded up to the 10th NFL Draft pick to swoop for Mahomes, a decision that would change the course of football history.

Brittany, however, was chasing her own dreams. In an opportunity she couldn't refuse at 22 years old, she had a chance to forge a professional soccer career in Iceland after an outstanding run in college with the University of Texas at Tyler. This was her first step on that journey and it forced the young couple, who had been together since the age of 15, into a long distance relationship.

As they touched down in Europe, Patrick was spotted by a group of Chiefs fans, about 3,300 miles away from Kansas City, who raced over to greet their surprised new quarterback. If the boy from Texas didn't already know how famous he was quickly becoming, it was another thing he was having to learn fast.

Then, out of the crowd came another figure in Sigurbjart Sigurjonsson, the president of the Icelandic team Brittany was playing for, and the man whose home they would be staying in.

'I had no idea who he was,' Sigurjonsson said. 'He was here with her for ten days, exploring the country. We didn't suspect he was some kind of star. They often asked where they could go to eat, and we always suggested moderately expensive places because we didn't think they had much money.'

Ironically, the opposite was true. Mahomes' rookie contract with the Chiefs was worth $16.4milion - making him a billionaire in Iceland.

They stayed in the small town of Mosfellsbaer in the east of the country, renowned for its natural beauty. As Brittany settled in, they explored hiking trails, visited lagoons and went whale watching. But Patrick still made time to study his playbook.

'I didn't always understand what he was doing with a flimsy folder that he was constantly looking through,' Sigurjonsson said in 2018. 'Of course, he was going over all the systems and preparing for the season.' 

An NFL quarterback for a house guest wasn't easy. The beds in Sigurjonsson's spare room weren't big enough for Mahomes and his 6-foot 2, 225-pound frame.

'He was too big for the beds, so he had to sleep on the couch,' Sigurjonsson explained. 'It turned out to be difficult to host him.'

But otherwise, the young couple were unassuming as they explored one of Europe's most fascinating countries.

'We sometimes joke that he could have bought the whole block, set it on fire and not noticed,' Sigurjonsson said. 'He got to live with me for free and enjoyed it.'

After nine nights on the sofa, Patrick headed back to the United States and Brittany began her shot at making it as a professional in the other football. In 2013, she had gone to Texas Taylor as an aspiring cheerleader before friends encouraged her to return to the soccer field.

'I don't know where it came from,' she said years later, reflecting on her college time. 'In my senior year, I just got this insane attitude, drive, where I was like "I'm not losing."

When she put pen to paper on her contract to go and play in Iceland in May of 2017, she was determined to become a star.

'These last four years (at college) have made me fall in love with soccer all over again and want to go on and play professional,' she said. 'An opportunity opened up for me in Iceland and I could never pass up such an amazing experience to go do what I love.'

Without Patrick she began training harder than ever, gaining three pounds of muscle and developing a passion for fitness that remains to this day. But that newfound strength, however, was not enough to translate to success on the field for UMF Afturelding/Fram.

'She wasn't the best player even though she was a nice girl,' Sigurjonsson said. 'She just wasn't strong enough for the Inkasso league here at home so we decided not to sign her.'

Brittany struggled too, with the distance from her family and especially with the distance from her parents while Patrick was locked in on his new NFL responsibilities.

She eventually left having made five appearances for the team, scoring twice, and on her return to America joined Patrick in Kansas City where she tried to forge a new career as a fitness influencer.

'Setting down roots in Kansas City was huge for us. I think the people are what we love the most about Kansas City,' Patrick said when Brittany joined him. 'We're trying to be here for a long, long time.'

'By the end of my first season, I truly began to fall in love with being in the gym more than being on the soccer field,' she said on the website where she launched her personal training work.

'Playing sports my whole life got me into fitness and playing in college taught me about strength training, wellness and maintaining peak fitness to perform at an elite level.'

In December 2020, the same year Patrick won his first Super Bowl with the Chiefs, the National Women's Soccer League awarded an expansion team to the Kansas City Current, where Brittany is part of the ownership group.

Patrick joined that group in 2023, and the couple regularly attend games in the first stadium in the world that is purpose-built for a professional women's team. Brittany also makes effort to be available for the players and forge relationships with them away from the sport.

USWNT international and Current striker Michelle Cooper told People: 'She drops in a lot. She comes and says hi to the girls, and she's awesome.'

And of course, since September 2023 her profile has rocketed amid her friendship with Taylor Swift. The pair have built a close bond, despite Brittany's support for Donald Trump being at odds with Swift, who backed Kamala Harris and the Democratic party at the last election.

She's sure to have a front-row seat as Swift and Mahomes' Chiefs teammate Travis Kelce get married in Rhode Island later this year - a wedding the whole world will be watching.

It's a far cry from the fjords of Iceland and something neither Brittany nor Patrick could have imagined when they landed in Reykjavik in 2017.
news.summary: Of all places, it was an airport in Iceland where the future with the Kansas City Chiefs, for a moment at least, may have felt overwhelming for¬†Patrick Mahomes.¬†
news.author: Editor,Jack Bezants

news.title: The Washington Stand: NIH Discontinues Fetal Tissue Research Funding
news.text:
By Joshua Arnold

The day before the 2026 March for Life, the Trump administration announced a pro-life policy change that advocates have pursued for more than two decades. ‚ÄúEffective the date of this Notice,‚Äù announced the National Institutes of Health (NIH), ‚ÄúNIH funds will not be permitted for research using HFT [human fetal tissue] from elective abortions.‚Äù In response to the announcement, Science Alliance for Life and Technology President Dr. David Prentice cheered, ‚ÄúThis is a win not just for human dignity, but also for science ‚Äî and the promotion of ethical science that respects every human life.‚Äù

Pro-life advocates have pointed out the ethical issues behind funding such research for years. After an unborn baby is aborted, the child‚Äôs remains are then sold to researchers who use them as raw material for experiments intended to promote health science. In reality, ‚Äúhuman fetal tissue‚Äù is a euphemism for what the average person would easily recognize as ‚Äúunborn baby body parts.‚Äù

Journalist David Daleiden vividly illustrated this fact in 2015 when he published undercover videos showing Planned Parenthood employees deliberately carrying out an abortion in a way to maximize the saleable value of the baby‚Äôs body parts. ‚ÄúDavid Daleiden‚Äôs undercover videos exposing the trafficking in baby body parts opened the eyes of the nation to this horrific research endeavor and helped pave the way to the current decision,‚Äù Prentice assessed.

The graphic videos provoked a furious reaction, and Daleiden was targeted with a multi-year prosecution by then-California Attorney General Kamala Harris and her successor in office, then-Attorney General Xavier Becerra. Of course, these figures went on to serve as vice president and HHS secretary in the Biden administration.

However, not all medical research conducted with human remains is unethical. Ethically speaking, a wide chasm exists between a dying person donating their body to science and an unscrupulous profiteer deliberately ending a person‚Äôs life to sell their organs ‚Äî like the Chinese Communist Party‚Äôs practice of organ harvesting.

NIH did not ban all research with human fetal tissue; it prohibited funding for research using tissue obtained through elective abortion, while conceding, ‚ÄúNIH funds are permitted for use of research involving HFT obtained from miscarriage or stillbirth.‚Äù However, Prentice set this allowance in context, ‚ÄúFetal tissue research from ethically derived sources can still continue, but the newer, more modern alternatives will likely supplant those tissue sources as well.‚Äù

‚ÄúModern science has developed numerous successful and ethical alternatives to the use of aborted human fetal tissue,‚Äù Prentice told TWS. ‚ÄúTherapies from adult stem cells, production of ‚Äòmouse models‚Äô using umbilical cord blood, and development models using organoids that faithfully replicate human organ development all provide ethical and more effective alternatives to aborted baby body parts. After decades of fighting against the unethical research with fetal tissue, it‚Äôs good to see that grisly chapter of human experiments closed.‚Äù

‚ÄúNIH is pushing American biomedical science into the 21st century,‚Äù NIH Director Jay Bhattacharya explained. ‚ÄúThis decision is about advancing science by investing in breakthrough technologies more capable of modeling human health and disease. Under President Trump‚Äôs leadership, taxpayer-funded research must reflect the best science of today and the values of the American people.‚Äù

As an additional justification, Bhattacharya also cited ‚ÄúNIH‚Äôs responsibility to ensure that research supported by taxpayer funds is scientifically rigorous, ethically sound, and justified by a maximal return on the public‚Äôs investment.‚Äù

In its Thursday announcement, NIH revealed that ‚ÄúNIH-supported research using human fetal tissue has declined steadily since 2019, with only 77 projects funded in Fiscal Year 2024.‚Äù This decline is due both to the advent of more promising alternative technologies and to the work of the Human Fetal Tissue Research Ethics Advisory Board. In 2020, NIH established the board to make recommendations about ‚Äúwhether the Secretary [of Health and Human Services] should withhold funds or not withhold funds from a proposed project because of ethical considerations.‚Äù

Going back to the George W. Bush administration, pro-life advocates have called for an end to government funding of research using the remains of aborted babies. However, researchers countered that such research greatly benefited medical science and would soon lead to abundant cures. With the help of a sympathetic media establishment and the abortion lobby, the pragmatic arguments drowned out moral ones.

When the debate reached its height, Prentice took a sabbatical from his professorship at Indiana State University to scientifically defend the pro-life position. He argued that fetal stem cells were ‚Äúill-suited for clinical use,‚Äù had trouble integrating into the body, and could trigger a hostile immune response. For his efforts, the university punished Prentice, reducing his teaching assignments and lab privileges.

Pro-life advocates had greater success persuading the first Trump administration to curtail the research practice, and the second Trump administration has now finished the job by cutting off all federal funding to research using aborted human fetal tissue.

Prentice concluded, ‚ÄúMy colleagues in our new organization, Science Alliance for Life and Technology (SALT), are gratified to see the years of struggle to disseminate the truth pay off in this new announcement from NIH.‚Äù

Joshua Arnold is a senior writer at The Washington Stand.
news.author: Joshua Arnold

news.title: What to expect in Minnesota's special legislative elections
news.text:
WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî Two special elections Tuesday in heavily Democratic Twin Cities-area state legislative districts will decide control of the Minnesota House of Representatives for the third time in less than a year.

Republicans hold a 67-65 advantage in the chamber after two Democratic representatives were elected to other offices in November. The chamber has operated under a power-sharing agreement between the two parties for much of the last year.

The contests take place just days after a U.S. Border Patrol agent fatally shot a man in Minneapolis, sparking protests and renewed calls for federal immigration officers to leave the state. Earlier in January, an Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer shot and killed a Minneapolis woman as part of an ongoing federal immigration crackdown.

In District 47A, Democrat Shelley Buck is the only candidate on the ballot, although voters have the option to vote for a write-in candidate. Buck is a former environmental nonprofit executive and former president of the Prairie Island Tribal Council.

The district is east of St. Paul. It falls mostly within Washington County but includes a portion of Ramsey County. In 2024, both Democratic state Rep. Amanda Hemmingsen-Jaeger and Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris carried District 47A with about 61% of the vote in their races. Hemmingsen-Jaeger won a special election to the state Senate in 2025.

In District 64A, the nominees are Democrat Meg Luger-Nikolai and Republican Dan Walsh. Luger-Nikolai is a labor attorney who represented a statewide teachers union. Walsh runs a real estate property management company and has worked in cybersecurity and tech sales. He was the GOP nominee for this seat in 2022 and 2024.

The district is entirely within Ramsey County and stretches most of the distance between St. Paul and Minneapolis. Democratic state Rep. Kaohly Her and Harris each won the district with more than 83% of the vote in 2024. Her was elected mayor of St. Paul in 2025.

With Buck the only candidate on the ballot in District 47A, The Associated Press will treat the contest as uncontested and will call the race as soon as polls close, unless there is any indication of an organized write-in effort for another candidate.

In District 64A, Walsh will need to far outperform the approximately 15% and 17% of the vote he received in his 2022 and 2024 runs, respectively. With almost all the vote expected to be released in just one or two batches, a race call could be possible at the first sign of an overwhelming margin.

The Associated Press does not make projections and will declare a winner only when it‚Äôs determined there is no scenario that would allow the trailing candidates to close the gap. If a race has not been called, the AP will continue to cover any newsworthy developments, such as candidate concessions or declarations of victory. In doing so, the AP will make clear that it has not yet declared a winner and explain why.

There are no automatic recounts for state legislative races in Minnesota. A losing candidate may request a publicly funded recount if the margin is less than 0.5% of the total vote. The AP may declare a winner in a race that is eligible for a recount if it can determine the lead is too large for a recount or legal challenge to change the outcome.

Here are some of the key facts about the election and data points the AP Decision Desk will monitor as the votes are tallied:

When do polls close?

8 p.m. local time, which is 9 p.m. ET.

What‚Äôs on the ballot?

The AP will provide vote results and declare winners in the special elections for Minnesota state House Districts 47A and 64A.

Who gets to vote?

The special elections are open to voters in state House Districts 47A and 64A. Minnesota allows voters to register on Election Day at their polling place.

What do turnout and advance vote look like?

House Districts 47A and 64A each had nearly 28,000 registered voters as of June 1, 2025.

In District 47A, about 23,000 voters cast ballots in the 2024 general election and about 19,000 in 2022. About half the ballots in 2024 were cast before Election Day, compared with about 31% in the 2022 midterm elections. 

In District 64A, nearly 25,000 voters cast ballots in 2024 and more than 21,000 in 2022. About 41% of ballots in 2024 were cast before Election Day, compared with about 27% in the 2022 midterm elections.

As of Thursday night, just shy of 300 ballots had already been cast in District 47A and about 400 ballots in District 64A.

How long does vote-counting usually take?

In the 2022 general election, the AP first reported results at 10:49 p.m. ET in District 47A and at 11:12 p.m. ET in District 64A. The last vote update of the night in District 47A was at 11:50 p.m. ET and in District 64A was at 11:39 p.m. ET, each with more than 99% of the total vote counted.

In the 2024 general election, the AP first reported results in both Districts 47A and 64A at 1:09 a.m. ET. The tabulation in both districts ended for the night at 2:29 a.m. ET with more than 99% of total votes counted.

When are early and absentee votes released?

In previous elections in both Ramsey and Washington counties, results from absentee voting were released along with in-person Election Day voting throughout the night.
news.author: Robert Yoon

False Equivalence

From the skeletons in brothels to the child sacrifice of the Mayans, the mark of barbarism is that we treat babies like inconveniences to be discarded rather than the blessings to cherish that they are. ‚Ä¶ The March for Life ‚Ä¶ is about whether we will remain a civilization under God or we whether we ultimately return to the paganism that dominated the past.‚Äù ‚ÄîVice President JD Vance

Roasting Gavin, Again

But to say strange things like, ‚ÄòPresident Trump is a Tyrannosaurus rex‚Äô ‚Äî what the [heck] does that mean? I could say, ‚ÄòGavin Newsom is a Brontosaurus with a brain the size of a walnut.‚Äô‚Äù ‚ÄîTreasury Secretary Scott Bessent
