news.title: Tim Walz vs ICE: Why MAGA‚Äôs ‚ÄòTampon Tim‚Äô nickname is back
news.text: Amid ongoing protests against ICE in Minnesota, Governor Tim Walz and the Trump administration have been locked in a prolonged war of words. While the Democratic vice-presidential nominee has been urging Donald Trump to withdraw ICE agents from the state, MAGA supporters have been attacking Walz with the nickname ‚ÄòTampon Tim,‚Äô blaming his policies for what they allege is a surge in immigration.‚ÄúWhy are ICE protests so widespread in Minnesota and nowhere else? It is because Tampon Tim and Frey are fanning the flames to cover up for the fraud. Shame on them!‚Äù read a recent post on X that made use of the nickname.As the verbal sparring continues, many are asking why Walz, a 61-year-old politician, is repeatedly referred to as ‚ÄòTampon Tim‚Äô by Trump supporters. Political nicknames and trolling are nothing new, but what is the story behind this one?‚ÄòTampon Tim‚ÄôPolitics is a game of blames and names and when a crisis occurs, each side throws both at each other. While Walz may not have been witty enough to think of one, Republicans were quick to award him with an alias: 'Tampon Tim'. The label gained traction after 2024 presidential candidate Kamala Harris announced Walz as her vice-presidential pick.At its core the name is a dig at one of Walz's policies launched in 2023. The governor signed a law requiring public schools to provide menstrual products including pads and tampons to students from grades 4 to 12. It went into effect on January 1, 2024, making Minnesota one of the twenty-eight states to have passed laws giving access to menstrual products to students. The bill's inclusive language reflects that not all people who menstruate are women and not all women get periods, therefore, the products were made available in all bathrooms regardless of gender.For anti-transgender Republicans, this became an immediate point of attack. ‚ÄúTim Walz is a weird radical liberal,‚Äù the MAGA War Room account posted on X, formerly Twitter, at the time. ‚ÄúWhat could be weirder than signing a bill requiring schools to stock tampons in boys' bathrooms?‚Äù From editing Walz's face on tampons to criticising him in social media posts, they continue to do it all. But when you zoom in deeper, it's not just about policies, it's also about the ancient taboos of uncleanness and shame, associated with menstruation and women. In the Bible, the book of Leviticus defined menstruating women, and any who touched them, as unclean, and the book of Isaiah compared false idols to menstrual cloths which must be cast away. Still, many assume menstrual blood is disgusting to men and essentially when Republicans chant 'Tampon Tim' what they are screaming louder is 'ew, gross periods.' They are projecting their disdain for feminine nature and slyly calling Walz 'feminine', which to many of them is the most insulting thing you can call a man.Democrats push backWhile Republicans appear fond of the alliterative jab, Democrats have not responded with embarrassment. ‚ÄúHow nice of the Trump camp to help publicise Gov. Tim Walz‚Äôs compassionate and common-sense policy of providing free menstrual products to students in Minnesota public schools,‚Äù Hillary Clinton wrote in a post on X at the time.The nickname has endured, resurfacing as Republicans and Democrats clash over ICE enforcement in Minnesota. Political labels have a long shelf life, and when one fails to land as intended, they are often repurposed‚Äîsometimes even embraced by the opposition.What ‚ÄòTampon Tim‚Äô ultimately underscores is that Walz once championed a version of masculinity rooted in empathy and public welfare‚Äîan idea praised by supporters and ridiculed by critics, but difficult to erase from the political conversation.
news.author: Toi Trending Desk

news.title: Spiuni i rremë që mashtroi një kompani nafte me vlerë 350 milionë dollarë
news.text:
Kur Niels Troost u takua p√´r her√´ t√´ par√´ me Gaurav Srivastava-n, ai mendoi se problemet e tij kishin marr√´ fund.

Tregtari i naft√´s me origjin√´ holandeze, i cili p√´r vite me radh√´ kishte tregtuar naft√´ ruse, po p√´rballej me sanksione t√´ mundshme amerikane pas pushtimit t√´ Ukrain√´s nga Vladimir Putini n√´ vitin 2022. Srivastava, nj√´ biznesmen indian q√´ jetonte n√´ Kaliforni, tha se ishte i pozicionuar n√´ m√´nyr√´ unike p√´r ta ndihmuar.

Srivastava i tregoi Troost-in nj√´ sekret: ai n√´ t√´ v√´rtet√´ ishte nj√´ operativ i CIA-s, q√´ p√´rdorte aktivitetet e tij t√´ biznesit si mbules√´, dhe e arg√´toi at√´ me histori personale p√´r intriga nd√´rkomb√´tare dhe b√´ma t√´ guximshme.

Biznesmeni rreth t√´ tridhjetave foli p√´r trajnimin e tij n√´ ‚ÄúThe Farm‚Äù, kompleksi i CIA-s n√´ Virxhinia, tregoi plag√´ nga nj√´ mision i fsheht√´ dhe p√´rshkroi se si ishte mbajtur peng nga ISIS-i n√´ vitin 2008 gjat√´ nj√´ operacioni n√´ Republik√´n Demokratike t√´ Kongos.

P√´r t√´ forcuar besueshm√´rin√´ e tij, Srivastava ndau fotografi t√´ vetes me figura t√´ r√´nd√´sishme politike dhe ushtarake, nga presidenti Joe Biden te ish-komandanti suprem i NATO-s, gjenerali Wesley Clark.

Por historit√´ e jasht√´zakonshme q√´ rr√´fente Srivastava ishin t√´ sajuara, pretendon Troost n√´ nj√´ padi RICO (Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act), nj√´ akuz√´ se ai kishte nd√´rtuar nj√´ skem√´ t√´ organizuar mashtrimi dhe shantazhi p√´r t√´ vjedhur para dhe kompani. Padia thot√´ se Srivastava nuk ka qen√´ kurr√´ n√´ CIA. Ajo thot√´ se ‚Äúplag√´t e betej√´s‚Äù n√´ fakt vinin nga nj√´ operacion n√´ veshka gjat√´ f√´mij√´ris√´ dhe se rr√´mbimi nga ISIS nuk mund t√´ ket√´ ndodhur sepse organizata terroriste ‚Äúnuk operonte n√´ RDK n√´ vitin 2008, dhe asnj√´ grup i lidhur me ISIS-in nuk ekzistonte n√´ at√´ rajon n√´ at√´ koh√´.‚Äù

N√´ padin√´ e tij t√´ re RICO, Troost pretendon se Srivastava ishte nj√´ ‚Äúspiun i rrem√´‚Äù q√´ kishte g√´njyer p√´r pun√´n e tij p√´r CIA-n si pjes√´ e nj√´ p√´rpjekjeje p√´r t‚Äôi vjedhur kompanin√´ prej 350 milion√´ dollar√´sh. Srivastava k√´rkonte parat√´, pjes√´risht, p√´r t√´ bler√´ nj√´ rezidenc√´ n√´ Kaliforni prej 24.5 milion√´ dollar√´sh, pemishte dhe nj√´ streh√´ kund√´r bombave q√´ sh√´rbente si bodrum vere, sipas padis√´ s√´ Troost.

‚ÄúP√´r m√´ shum√´ se pes√´ vjet, i pandehuri Gaurav Srivastava drejtoi nj√´ nd√´rmarrje kriminale q√´ vodhi dhe shantazhoi dhjet√´ra miliona dollar√´ nga padit√´sit dhe viktima t√´ tjera mbi baz√´n e narrativ√´s s√´ rreme gjith√´p√´rfshir√´se se Srivastava ishte nj√´ operativ i nivelit t√´ lart√´ i CIA-s n√´ mbulim jozyrtar,‚Äù thuhet n√´ padi.

‚ÄúSrivastava dhe an√´tar√´t e tjer√´ t√´ nd√´rmarrjes mashtruan viktimat duke i bindur se Srivastava kontrollonte fuqin√´ e qeveris√´ s√´ Shteteve t√´ Bashkuara dhe mund t√´ ofronte ndihm√´ t√´ pa√ßmueshme p√´r aleat√´t e tij dhe t√´ shkat√´rronte ata q√´ guxonin ta sfidonin. E gjitha kjo ishte nj√´ trillim i plot√´. Srivastava nuk √´sht√´ dhe nuk ka qen√´ kurr√´ operativ i CIA-s, apo agjent i ndonj√´ agjencie tjet√´r federale amerikane. Ai nuk √´sht√´ as qytetar amerikan. Ai √´sht√´ thjesht nj√´ mashtrues.‚Äù

Sot, kompania e Troost-it √´sht√´ n√´ proces mbylljeje dhe po shet t√´ gjitha asetet p√´r t√´ shlyer borxhet, zbulon padia.

Avokati Jason Masimore, nj√´ ish-prokuror federal q√´ p√´rfaq√´son Troost-in, i tha The Independent: ‚ÄúPadia dhe provat mb√´shtet√´se zbulojn√´ nj√´ komplot kriminal masiv t√´ orkestruar n√´ SHBA nga udh√´heq√´si i tij, Gaurav Srivastava.‚Äù

Srivastava ishte n√´ gjendje ta realizonte skem√´n e supozuar vet√´m fal√´ nj√´ s√´r√´ njer√´zish q√´ e ndihmonin, avokat√´, bankier√´ dhe ish-operativ√´ t√´ inteligjenc√´s, sipas Masimore, i cili tha se komploti kishte kompromentuar sigurin√´ komb√´tare t√´ SHBA-s√´ dhe nivelet m√´ t√´ larta t√´ udh√´heqjes politike.

‚ÄúTroost dhe kompanit√´ e tij k√´rkojn√´ t‚Äôi mbajn√´ t√´ pandehurit p√´rgjegj√´s p√´r sjelljen e tyre t√´ d√´nueshme,‚Äù tha Masimore.

Padia √´sht√´ hapi m√´ e fundit n√´ nj√´ sag√´ t√´ gjat√´ mes dy burrave, q√´ p√´rfshin an√´tar√´ t√´ komunitetit t√´ inteligjenc√´s, senator√´ amerikan√´, zyrtar√´ t√´ huaj qeveritar√´ dhe madje edhe yllin e muzik√´s pop John Legend.

√ãsht√´ padia e par√´ q√´ e em√´ron personalisht Srivastava-n si t√´ pandehur. Padi t√´ m√´parshme kan√´ synuar ndihm√´sit e supozuar t√´ Srivastava-s, p√´rfshir√´ nj√´ firm√´ t√´ inteligjenc√´s korporative dhe komunikimit t√´ krizave, e drejtuar nga veteran√´ me ndikim t√´ CIA-s, p√´r t√´ cil√´n Troost thot√´ se zhvilloi nj√´ fushat√´ t√´ sh√´mtuar shpifjeje kund√´r tij n√´ em√´r t√´ ish-partnerit t√´ tij t√´ biznesit.

Srivastava nuk iu p√´rgjigj k√´rkesave p√´r koment t√´ d√´rguara n√´ adresat e tij personale dhe t√´ biznesit, as p√´rmes avokatit t√´ tij. Edhe Grupi Arkin, q√´ Troost e ka paditur ve√ßmas p√´r shpifje, nuk reagoi. Nd√´rkoh√´, avokati i Troost, Jason Masimore, ka gjithashtu nj√´ padi p√´r shpifje kund√´r Srivastava-s n√´ gjykat√´ federale.

N√´ nj√´ padi t√´ m√´parshme kund√´r Arkin, e transferuar nga gjykata federale n√´ Gjykat√´n Supreme t√´ Nju Jorkut, √ß√´shtja u p√´rshkrua si nj√´ histori me ‚Äútipare filmi hollivudian, spiun√´ t√´ rrem√´, vjedhje dhe mashtrim‚Äù, por me akuza n√´ thelb ‚Äúmjaft t√´ thjeshta‚Äù. Arkin ka mohuar se Srivastava ka punuar ndonj√´her√´ p√´r CIA-n ose se √´sht√´ paraqitur si i till√´.

N√´ padin√´ e tij t√´ re RICO n√´ Los Anxhelos, Troost paraqet akuza t√´ r√´nda ndaj Srivastava-s, i p√´rshkruar dikur nga The Wall Street Journal si ‚Äúpjes√´risht Austin Powers, pjes√´risht James Bond‚Äù. Edhe pse Srivastava mohon t√´ jet√´ paraqitur si spiun, padia p√´rfshin transkripte telefonike ku ai e p√´rshkruan veten si operativ n√´ ‚Äúmbulim jozyrtar‚Äù.

Sipas Troost-it, p√´r vite me radh√´ Srivastava nd√´rtoi nj√´ mashtrim t√´ nd√´rlikuar, duke u shtirur si oficer i CIA-s, duke shpikur misione inteligjence dhe duke p√´rdorur k√´t√´ identitet t√´ rrem√´ p√´r t√´ siguruar para, akses dhe ndikim. Padia pretendon se ai ka mashtruar m√´ par√´ biznesmen√´ afrikan√´, zyrtar√´ qeveritar√´ dhe madje edhe spiun√´ amerikan√´.

Troost, nj√´ tregtar veteran i naft√´s, thot√´ se u b√´ sh√´njest√´r kur nj√´ bashk√´pun√´tor e k√´rc√´noi se do ta diskreditonte si agjent t√´ Kremlinit pas fillimit t√´ luft√´s n√´ Ukrain√´. Ai iu drejtua nj√´ kontakti q√´ e lidhi me ‚ÄúZ. G‚Äù, Srivastava, i cili i premtoi se do t√´ ndalte sulmet dhe se kishte ndikim p√´rmes nj√´ programi t√´ CIA-s q√´ monitoronte naft√´n ruse.

Sipas padis√´, Srivastava e bindi Troost-in se kishte mb√´shtetje nga nivelet m√´ t√´ larta t√´ qeveris√´ amerikane, p√´rfshir√´ Biden-in, Kamala Harris, Jake Sullivan dhe Chuck Schumer. Ai madje pretendonte se kishte nd√´rmjet√´suar marr√´veshje arm√´sh dhe kishte ndikuar n√´ listat e ndalimit t√´ SHBA-s√´ p√´r zyrtar√´ t√´ huaj.

N√´ korrik 2022, Srivastava e bindi Troost-in t‚Äôi shiste gjysm√´n e kompanis√´ Paramount me √ßmim t√´ ul√´t, duke th√´n√´ se ishte e vetmja m√´nyr√´ p√´r t√´ shmangur sanksionet dhe p√´r t√´ vazhduar tregtin√´ e naft√´s ruse. M√´ von√´, p√´rmes transfertave t√´ nd√´rlikuara, ai dyshohet se nxori dhjet√´ra miliona dollar√´ nga kompania, p√´rfshir√´ 25 milion√´ p√´r t√´ bler√´ nj√´ vil√´ luksoze n√´ Los Anxhelos.

Kur Troost filloi t√´ dyshonte dhe e p√´rballi, Srivastava e k√´rc√´noi se do ta etiketonte si agjent rus dhe do t‚Äôi bllokonte asetet. Pas prishjes s√´ marr√´veshjes n√´ maj 2023, Srivastava dyshohet se nisi nj√´ fushat√´ agresive shpifjeje p√´rmes Grupit Arkin, duke p√´rhapur histori t√´ rreme q√´ e lidhin Troost-in dhe familjen e tij me krimin dhe Rusin√´.

Ekspozimet n√´ The Wall Street Journal dhe Financial Times n√´ vitet 2024‚Äì2025 e √ßmontuan figur√´n publike t√´ Srivastava-s dhe e shtyn√´ at√´ t√´ zhvendosej nga qarqet demokrate drejt atyre republikane, duke u shfaqur n√´ konventa konservatore dhe pran√´ figurave si Z√´vend√´spresidenti J.D. Vance.

Nd√´rkoh√´, Troost u sanksionua nga Mbret√´ria e Bashkuar, BE-ja dhe Zvicra, dhe kompania e tij u detyrua t√´ mbyllej. Padia RICO k√´rkon kthimin e parave t√´ p√´rfituara n√´ m√´nyr√´ t√´ paligjshme dhe d√´mshp√´rblime t√´ shum√´fishuara, nd√´rsa Srivastava ende nuk ka dh√´n√´ nj√´ p√´rgjigje zyrtare. / The Independent
news.author: Megi Dumi

news.title: What MAGA Can Teach Democrats About Organizing‚Äîand Infighting
news.text:
Dare, or the Drug Abuse Resistance Education program, was created in 1983 by the Los Angeles Police Department and the Los Angeles County school district. From the start, the program was a success. Its stated goal was ‚Äúto equip elementary-school children with skills for resisting peer pressure to experiment with tobacco, drugs and alcohol.‚Äù The initiative was embraced by police departments and politicians, and within just a few years the Dare curriculum had spread to more than three-quarters of the country‚Äôs school districts. More than three million students participated annually, and many were taught that even one toke can end in homelessness and despair. The group received admiring press, and was funded by Congress and various philanthropies; the budget at Dare headquarters eventually approached twenty-five million dollars a year. Nancy Reagan and the White House praised the program, and it received support from major companies, from Kmart to Kentucky Fried Chicken.
madd‚Äôs origins were far less auspicious; even to its founders it seemed like a long shot. In 1980, Cari Lightner, a thirteen-year-old girl who lived outside Sacramento, was killed by a drunk driver while walking to church. The man had previously been arrested four times for driving while drunk but had mostly avoided serious punishment‚Äîa pattern that continued when he was found guilty of vehicular manslaughter for Lightner‚Äôs death but given a sentence of only twenty-one months, with a portion spent in a halfway house. In response, Lightner‚Äôs mother, Candy, quit her job in real estate to found Mothers Against Drunk Driving. On her own, she began lobbying legislators, telephoning journalists, and appearing on newscasts, pushing for tougher drunk-driving laws. Eventually, women in other cities‚Äîmany of whom had also been affected by drunk driving‚Äîsaw those newscasts and read those articles. They sent Lightner letters asking for permission to launch madd chapters in their towns. She often mailed such volunteers a few pages with advice on how to contact local judges, monitor court cases, and petition legislators. But she essentially gave them permission to use whatever attention-getting tactics they thought best.
On an organizational level, Dare and madd were quite different. Dare was overseen from a central headquarters, in L.A., where staff guided nearly every aspect of operations. As Dare spread across the nation, it became an oft-cited example of what scholars of social movements call ‚Äúmobilizing‚Äù‚Äîthe process of educating people about a cause and then prompting them to participate in public events. When, in 1988, President Ronald Reagan declared the first National Dare Day, and hundreds of school districts let children miss classes to attend boisterous anti-drug rallies, this was mobilizing at work.
madd, by contrast, wasn‚Äôt particularly focussed on mobilizing. Each of its chapters was independent and largely ungoverned by headquarters; volunteers concentrated on local advocacy instead of on national activism. As a result, local madd leaders often supported sets of policy recommendations that diverged‚Äîor even conflicted‚Äîwith the agendas of other chapters. Some MADD chapters pushed to prohibit alcohol sales at public events, objected to accepting funding from alcohol companies, and advocated for mandatory jail time; others argued that the group shouldn‚Äôt be anti-drinking but, rather, anti-drunk-driving, that it should welcome donations from beverage companies, and that courts should have discretion over sentencing. Meanwhile, at the top of madd, there were serious managerial problems. Lightner, who was known to staff members as the madd Queen, sometimes used the organization‚Äôs funds to pay for personal expenses, including dry cleaning and babysitting. In 1985, after reports revealed that a telemarketing firm hired by madd had pocketed much of the donations to the group in fees, the California attorney general opened an investigation. A new executive director quit after seventeen months; then a new board pushed out Lightner, who responded by criticizing the organization in the press.
All this turmoil, however, had the knock-on effect of making madd excel at another important aspect of social movements‚Äîwhat‚Äôs known as ‚Äúorganizing,‚Äù helping members to become leaders on their own. The chaos at headquarters led to the empowerment of local chapter heads and allowed the social bonding that a movement needs to survive. Moreover, chapter members were free to experiment with different tactics. Mark Wolfson, a professor at the University of California, Riverside, who has studied the group, has likened it to a franchise business in which a new owner is given just a bit of instruction and is then expected to find a way to prosper. ‚Äúmadd kind of forced volunteers to step up,‚Äù he told me. He explained that the group‚Äôs members, many of them stay-at-home mothers with little professional experience, ‚Äúsuddenly had to figure out how to talk to politicians and go on TV and build a community and fund-raise and network‚Äîpretty heady stuff.‚Äù Not every madd chapter thrived, but for those that did, Wolfson said, ‚Äúit was an inadvertent leadership school on how to build organizations.‚Äù Lightner turned out to be easy to replace, because there were dozens of other leaders ready to take over.
As the Johns Hopkins political scientist Hahrie Han likes to say, ‚ÄúMobilizing is about getting people to do a thing, and organizing is about getting people to become the kind of people who do what needs to be done.‚Äù For a social movement to create real change, it helps to be skilled at both mobilizing and organizing. But that doesn‚Äôt mean that both skills are equally important. Dare was great at mobilizing‚Äîthe organization collected huge donations, charmed legislators, and spurred hundreds of rallies‚Äîbut it was largely ineffective at changing how people behaved. Multiple studies showed that some students even reported more drug use than nonparticipants, in part because the curriculum made them curious about experimenting. And, by the early two-thousands, many of the schools that had once been enrolled in Dare had dropped it. The program proved to be more of a fad than a movement.
madd, meanwhile, became one of the most successful advocacy groups in the U.S. Today, it has chapters in every state. madd has helped pass more than a thousand state laws, including one in New York, known as Leandra‚Äôs Law, that makes it an automatic felony to drive while intoxicated with someone age fifteen or younger in the car. madd was a pioneering advocate for victim-impact panels‚Äînamely, for allowing people affected by a crime to describe their experiences‚Äîwhich has become a common part of the criminal-justice system. The story of MADD suggests that organizing is more important than mobilizing.
One can look at the maga movement and the Democratic Party through a similar lens. Today‚Äôs Democratic Party is great at mobilizing: it can propel people into the streets with big marches, raise billions of dollars for national candidates, and get liberals to bombard congressional offices with letters and phone calls. However, it‚Äôs less talented at organizing‚Äîbuilding the kinds of local infrastructure and disparate leaders that are needed to sustain a large and ideologically diverse coalition. maga, on the other hand, is great at organizing‚Äîafter 2020, the movement launched the so-called Precinct Strategy, which encouraged thousands of people to run for leadership positions within their local Republican Party chapters, and to become poll workers. This is a reason Donald Trump is in the White House again‚Äîand liberal and conservative activists alike say that it will be hard for the Democrats to start consistently winning until they mimic some of Maga‚Äôs strategies.
Faith & Freedom was launched in direct response to the electoral success of a liberal: Barack Obama. In 2008, after the Democrats‚Äô sweeping victory of the White House and Congress, the longtime Republican operative Ralph Reed began studying exit polls to understand why so many conservatives who wouldn‚Äôt have dreamed of voting for Al Gore or John Kerry had supported Obama. Two decades earlier, Reed had been the executive director of the Christian Coalition, which had encouraged religious voters to turn out for conservative candidates. In 1994, the group helped deliver the House of Representatives to Republicans for the first time in forty years. In 2000, the coalition helped George W. Bush win the Presidency with around seventy per cent of the evangelical vote. By then, Reed, sensing more lucrative opportunities, had left the group to become a corporate public-affairs strategist.
After his departure, the Christian Coalition‚Äôs influence declined, but evangelicals continued to support Republicans. Then Obama emerged. As Reed examined canvassing records from the 2008 election, he found that Catholic voters, often stable Republicans, had supported Obama rather than the Republican candidate, Senator John McCain, by a nine-point margin. Obama had also outperformed previous Democrats with evangelical voters. Even among voters who attended worship services more than once a week, a reliable Republican bloc, Obama had increased his support by eight points. To Reed, these numbers were terrifying. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôve worked on campaigns as long as I have, you know when a slaughter‚Äôs coming,‚Äù Reed told me. ‚ÄúIt was here.‚Äù
How had Obama done it? To Reed and other political professionals, the answer seemed rooted, in part, in Obama‚Äôs willingness to ignore conventional wisdom about how campaigns ought to be run. Most Presidential races, once the primaries are over, rely on a large, professional staff to organize tens of thousands of volunteers. Although free labor can help a candidate win, volunteers are also seen as a source of risk, best restricted to such drudge work as phone banking or door knocking. Professionals worry that if volunteers are given too much freedom they‚Äôre likely to go off script, muddy the message, or spark social-media controversies.
Obama‚Äôs campaign, however, took the opposite approach. It recruited tens of thousands of volunteer leaders and basically told them to do what they thought best‚Äîin essence, to become franchises. These local leaders began experimenting with different messages and strategies, and then shared their results with one another. In Florida, a volunteer used her own money to rent an unofficial Obama campaign office while others built an ‚ÄúObama booth,‚Äù near a dog run, to register voters. In California, one particularly enthusiastic volunteer created an unofficial social-media account for Obama. (Webmasters eventually took it away.) After the official campaign built a website with instructions on how to create pro-Obama videos, more than four hundred thousand of them were uploaded to YouTube. This deliberately varied strategy vastly exceeded expectations; by many counts, it attracted more volunteers, who worked for more hours, than in any other campaign in U.S. history. In the 2008 and 2012 campaigns, a total of more than two million Obama supporters approached their neighbors and colleagues more than twenty-four million times, registering at least 1.8 million new voters and helping Obama and congressional Democrats secure victories.
As Reed saw it, Republicans had clearly been out-organized. In 2009, when he founded the Faith & Freedom Coalition, he adopted the franchise model that had propelled Obama (and madd). For instance, when Chad Schnitger, an organizer based in Riverside, California, asked Faith & Freedom‚Äôs headquarters about starting a local chapter, Reed‚Äôs lieutenants provided him with their blessing, some literature, and a small financial donation. But he was essentially on his own: he would need to find his own funding, develop his own strategies, and build his own network. Schnitger took advantage of this license and began contacting evangelical pastors and conservative nonprofits throughout Southern California. His pitch wasn‚Äôt about elections. ‚ÄúIt was that I understand organizing, and I‚Äôm a Christian,‚Äù he told me. ‚ÄúPastors want to be politically active‚Äîor, at least, to see their values having an impact in politics‚Äîbut they‚Äôre scared they‚Äôll get in trouble,‚Äù because churches and nonprofits are generally prohibited by I.R.S. rules from engaging in partisan campaigning. (Those rules changed slightly last year.)
Schnitger began e-mailing pastors with advice about what they could safely say from the pulpit on topics including school-board elections and tax proposals. He also began publishing regular newsletters with updates on such matters as homeschooling laws. Many parishioners in evangelical churches already belonged to small Bible-study groups‚Äîa tactic used by megachurches to help members bond‚Äîand Schnitger asked church leaders to nominate volunteers to serve as Faith & Freedom liaisons. ‚ÄúMy job is to build up the pastors and then encourage them to push leadership as far down as possible,‚Äù Schnitger told me. ‚ÄúI do for them what Faith & Freedom does for me.‚Äù When Schnitger ran out of churches to influence, he began approaching gun-club members and homeschooling associations. There wasn‚Äôt always ideological overlap among these groups. The people at gun clubs weren‚Äôt necessarily churchgoers; some homeschooling groups were wary of guns. ‚ÄúBut it doesn‚Äôt matter if they agree on everything,‚Äù Schnitger said. ‚ÄúThey just have to agree on who they‚Äôre voting for.‚Äù
Soon, Faith & Freedom had three hundred and fifty thousand members in California. Starting in 2020, after carefully studying the state‚Äôs ‚Äúballot harvesting‚Äù laws, Schnitger concluded that he could place boxes inside hundreds of churches, eventually collecting thousands of ballots each election.
Nationwide, there are 3.1 million Faith & Freedom members, and in 2024 they encouraged neighbors to vote for Trump nearly eighty million times‚Äîan outreach three times larger than Obama‚Äôs record-setting effort. The group‚Äôs headquarters distributes money, as well as write-ups about the results of local experiments, to the various chapters. But it‚Äôs up to local volunteers to decide which tactics to adopt and which issues to champion, as long as they align with the group‚Äôs basic conservative values.
If there‚Äôs a formula to Faith & Freedom‚Äôs success, Schnitger told me, ‚Äúit‚Äôs basically just being around‚Äîthat‚Äôs our whole secret. Instead of showing up at election time and asking for votes, we‚Äôre here year-round, asking people what they need.‚Äù Schnitger is selling community. ‚ÄúThe election is just the by-product,‚Äù he said.
This kind of organizing is hardly the only reason that Trump won. But scholars who study both parties agree that in recent decades Republicans have created broad ideological coalitions‚Äîsomething that Democrats, who tend to have litmus tests on abortion, social justice, and numerous other topics, have often not achieved. Conservatives have also built a media ecosystem that dwarfs Democratic messaging. Sarah Longwell, a longtime conservative strategist, opposes Trump‚Äôs autocratic transformation of the Republican Party, but she told me that the maga movement has nevertheless ‚Äúdone a fantastic job of welcoming anyone who puts on the red hat. That‚Äôs the only requirement‚Äîyou just have to think Trump is great.‚Äù
Kirk often spouted toxic right-wing rhetoric, including anti-gay and Islamophobic views, as well as antisemitic conspiracy theories. And a national field director of Turning Point resigned after it was revealed that she had declared, ‚ÄúI HATE BLACK PEOPLE! Like fuck them all.‚Äù But Kirk, at so-called Prove Me Wrong campus rallies across the nation, made a point of engaging with anyone who wanted to debate. When a gay student approached the microphone at a large Turning Point rally at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, Kirk said that he didn‚Äôt approve of the student‚Äôs ‚Äúlife style,‚Äù but he added that, if they could agree on, say, closing the border, then ‚Äúwe welcome you to the conservative movement.‚Äù At another event, he said to a liberal student who had been invited to speak, ‚ÄúYou know how we heal our divides? By talking to people we disagree with.‚Äù In September, Kirk was assassinated in front of three thousand students at Utah Valley University while debating a liberal audience member about gun control.
Colby Kelley, a former Turning Point leader at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, told me that the group‚Äôs ethos and loose organizational structure had pushed him to interact with all kinds of people he wouldn‚Äôt normally speak to, including socialists, anarchists, and attractive women. (He met his girlfriend at a Turning Point meeting.) ‚ÄúIt kind of teaches you to talk to everyone, because you never know who you‚Äôre going to agree with,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúJust because we argue doesn‚Äôt mean we have to dislike each other.‚Äù Of course, the liberals Kelley has engaged with may not have found these exchanges as satisfying as he did‚Äîsome of his interlocutors may have been offended. But Kirk‚Äôs Prove Me Wrong aesthetic was never about making liberals comfortable or converting them into Trump voters. Rather, it was about reassuring conservatives, of all kinds, that they could find a place within Turning Point USA.
As the effort became increasingly professionalized, its infrastructure began coming apart. Some activists objected to the event‚Äôs name, given its similarity to previous marches, including the incendiary Million Man March of 1995, which had been led by Louis Farrakhan of the Nation of Islam. The anti-Trump gathering was quickly rechristened the Women‚Äôs March, but soon afterward national organizers began issuing rules that struck some members as exclusionary. For one thing, women‚Äôs organizations that were anti-abortion were prohibited from participating. For another, participants who questioned some diversity-and-inclusion initiatives were not welcomed. Internal debates erupted about whether sex workers should be celebrated or seen as victims, and about the role of Jews in propagating racism. Shook distanced herself from the effort and called for the co-chairs to step down. These and other leaders bickered among themselves, accusing one another of racism and antisemitism. The turnout was impressive for the march itself. But, after, many of the groups created to put it on fell into factional infighting or drifted apart.
In the past century, Democrats have usually counted on outside organizations such as churches and labor unions to provide the kind of year-round, localized infrastructure that a movement needs to survive. But, as unions and non-evangelical churches have shrunk, the left has turned to a different strategy. It‚Äôs become largely focussed on creating spectacles, such as the No Kings protests, that can mobilize large numbers of people at breakneck speed to march, sign petitions, and contribute money. But much of the energy fizzles away once the protest or the election is over. Indeed, large gatherings and high-profile protests haven‚Äôt generally been effective at sparking widespread change: a recent study from the National Bureau of Economic Research, which looked at major U.S. social movements between 2017 and 2022, found that ‚Äúprotests generate substantial internet activity but have limited effects on political attitudes.‚Äù The researchers studied activism connected to the environment, gender equality, gun control, immigration, and other issues. Except for the myriad protests following the death of George Floyd, which may have slightly increased votes for Democrats, the researchers estimated ‚Äúnull effects of protests on public opinion and electoral behavior.‚Äù
According to Hahrie Han, the Johns Hopkins professor, part of the issue with modern progressive organizing is that ‚Äúdigital tools allow groups to scale really fast, but it also creates incentives to shortcut building infrastructure.‚Äù To take a far-off example, she said, during the Arab Spring, Twitter rallied people to topple dictators, ‚Äúbut the military was in power pretty soon afterward, because there wasn‚Äôt an infrastructure to sustain and channel that outrage.‚Äù Unlike at madd, where chapters were forced to build local communities and the dysfunction at headquarters allowed grassroots leaders to fill power vacuums, events like the Women‚Äôs March are usually national in focus, vacuums are filled by professional organizers, and strong local leaders seldom rise to top positions.
Even some of the most sophisticated left-leaning groups have stumbled. Following Trump‚Äôs victory in 2016, a group of former congressional staffers inspired by the pugnacity of Tea Party conservatives posted a rousing twenty-three-page online pamphlet titled ‚ÄúIndivisible: A Practical Guide for Resisting the Trump Agenda,‚Äù which encouraged such tactics as setting up Google News alerts for local congresspeople and spreading out at town halls to create the perception of broad support. The group also created a Google Doc to help activists across the country find one another. As with Dare, the initiative was quickly embraced by big donors and national leaders. In its first year, the group raised $2.6 million. Within two months, there were thousands of Indivisible chapters.
But, unlike the Tea Party, which at its founding was a chaotic jumble of anti-government viewpoints and competing leadership claims, Indivisible was tightly guided by its D.C. leaders and their dozens of employees. Tea Party activists often took the initiative to run in local races for school boards or county commissions; Indivisible‚Äôs headquarters focussed mostly on national issues and federal elections. The group‚Äôs national office scored some successes: it organized demonstrations against Trump‚Äôs Cabinet nominees and protested Republican attempts to repeal Obamacare. Yet there were structural problems. Initially, the group was a place for like-minded activists in numerous cities to convene, and various chapters started having success at backing local candidates. But organizational tensions emerged among Indivisible‚Äôs headquarters‚Äîstaffed by young political professionals who pushed for Medicare for All, the Green New Deal, and Elizabeth Warren‚Äôs candidacy for President‚Äîand many state volunteers, who, a 2021 study found, were largely ‚Äúolder white women‚Äù who didn‚Äôt necessarily agree with those stances and ‚Äúworked very hard to boost Democrats they understood held more moderate views.‚Äù
The author of that study, Theda Skocpol, a political scientist at Harvard, told me that Indivisible represents ‚Äúa tragic lost opportunity.‚Äù Local grassroots Indivisible groups were ‚Äúvery impactful on people running for office and winning,‚Äù she said, and they ‚Äúoperated pretty much on their own.‚Äù But the group‚Äôs top leaders, instead of building a sustainable and ideologically diverse membership, focussed on high-profile protests‚Äîand on maintaining ideological unity. At one point, the Indivisible headquarters discouraged chapters from endorsing candidates who were pro-life, or didn‚Äôt support gender-affirming care, or questioned making it easier for people to register to vote.
In her study, Skocpol wrote that, ‚Äúsince 2017, national Indivisible leaders have raised tens of millions of dollars from major donors, but have not devolved significant resources away from Washington, D.C., to empower democratically accountable state and local leaders. Instead, Indivisible directors have invested most of their resources into running a large, professionally staffed, national advocacy organization.‚Äù (Indivisible disputes Skocpol‚Äôs assessment and sent me a statement saying that it has ‚Äúenthusiastically campaigned for Democrats across the political spectrum.‚Äù)
Skocpol went on, ‚ÄúIf progressive-minded Americans want real change, most of the expertise, money and time we can muster should stop flowing into national advocacy bureaucracies engaged in symbolic maneuvers and purist politics.‚Äù
One problem, according to researchers, is that the left‚Äôs success in mobilizing large crowds may have caused leaders to misunderstand what spurs someone to become politically active in the first place. In the late nineties, the sociologist Ziad Munson began interviewing pro-life advocates, and he initially assumed that such people had been strongly opposed to abortion for years. ‚ÄúI was completely wrong,‚Äù he said. In fact, nearly a quarter of activists told him that they had been pro-choice when they attended their first pro-life event. A majority said that they had not had strong opinions about abortion. ‚ÄúBut then something happened, like they moved to a new town or started going to a new church, or they got divorced and started joining singles groups, and the new people they met were pro-life,‚Äù Munson explained. ‚ÄúAnd so they found a community, and a sense of identity, and that‚Äôs when they became committed.‚Äù
Many leaders of local MADD chapters first sought the group out after their lives had been upended by a drunk driver, and they found that meeting other victims helped them process their anger and grief. Wolfson, the madd researcher, told me, ‚ÄúThey were mainly women who had never thought of themselves as public figures, and now they‚Äôre talking to legislators and spending time with people who understand them and making new friends. At that point, you‚Äôre all in.‚Äù The organization accepted everyone, regardless of ideological background (and drinking habits). ‚ÄúAll you needed to join was to care about this issue.‚Äù
When researchers such as Munson look at today‚Äôs leftist movements, they often see the opposite approach. ‚ÄúThe left has purity tests,‚Äù Munson said. ‚ÄúYou have to prove you‚Äôre devoted to the cause. But that means that, once you join, you‚Äôre spending time with the kind of people you already know, because you already move in the same circles, and you‚Äôve screened out people who might be ideologically ambivalent right now but might have become activists if you had welcomed them.‚Äù
At pride marches in Chicago, New York, and Washington, D.C., organizers have refused or ejected participants because they were carrying rainbow flags with a Star of David. At a Cincinnati anti-white-supremacy rally, a rabbi was prohibited from speaking because, organizers said, ‚Äúallowing Zionists to participate undermines the original goal of the demonstration,‚Äù despite the rabbi‚Äôs vocal criticisms of the Israeli government. People have been excluded for other reasons: at Evergreen State College, in Olympia, Washington, an event called a Day of Absence, featuring discussions about racism, was cancelled after organizers asked white people to stay away from campus.
The sociologist Liz McKenna, of Harvard, told me that movements succeed best when people feel welcome. A movement becomes sustainable when members feel empowered and find friends. ‚ÄúThe left loves big protests, but protesting is a tactic in search of a strategy,‚Äù she said. There must be some shared core values among a movement‚Äôs members, of course, but the requirement can‚Äôt be that every value is shared. ‚ÄúMaking room for difference isn‚Äôt a nice-to-have thing‚Äîit‚Äôs table stakes,‚Äù she told me. ‚ÄúThe rallies are by-products of the community, not the goal.‚Äù Most of all, even though anger can be useful, a movement also needs to provide some joy. ‚ÄúTrump rallies are fun,‚Äù McKenna noted. ‚ÄúThe Turning Point campus debates are fun.‚Äù For a long time, she said, the left was less fun and more angry, ‚Äúand so the right was out-organizing them at every turn.‚Äù
Caldwell had a college degree and had been a professional her entire life. But now, as a convicted criminal, she couldn‚Äôt even get a job at a fast-food restaurant. When she saw a Facebook post mentioning that a new group was looking for people to organize rural communities, she signed up. An organizer told her that ‚Äúthey needed people to interview farmers and politicians,‚Äù Caldwell said. ‚ÄúAnd I was, like, ‚ÄòYou want a Black woman, and a convict, to get white people in Alamance to open up? Good luck!‚Äô ‚Äù
The group, Down Home North Carolina, had been created by Todd Zimmer after the state‚Äôs Republican legislators voted to refuse federal Medicaid funds. ‚ÄúThat money would have helped people see doctors,‚Äù Zimmer told me. ‚ÄúBut they wanted to send a message about Democratic overspending.‚Äù Zimmer holds fairly liberal views, at least on national issues. ‚ÄúBut, in rural areas, people are thinking about their neighborhood school, and whether the hospitals will stay open, and how much groceries cost,‚Äù he said. Most of North Carolina‚Äôs left-leaning organizations were focussed on big cities such as nearby Durham, where Democrats outnumber Republicans four to one. Zimmer figured that, if he could build a coalition of voters‚Äîboth progressives and right-wingers‚Äîwho might not agree on national candidates but were aligned on local issues, they could become one of the most powerful blocs in the state. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt pass a bill in North Carolina without rural places,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a fact. And so, if those places get organized, that‚Äôs where the power is.‚Äù
Zimmer‚Äôs strategy was to send people like Caldwell into parking lots at Walmart and Dollar General to ask residents what might spark them to action. The interviewees didn‚Äôt mention trans rights, Jeffrey Epstein, or other issues that were mainstays of cable news. Instead, they expressed worries about getting Narcan for relatives, where to bring vulnerable neighbors when summer temperatures spiked, and how to find affordable child care. Some complained about getting trapped in the same cash-bail system that had ensnared Caldwell. ‚ÄúAnd then we would ask them if they wanted to start a Down Home chapter in their city,‚Äù Zimmer said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd give them training and encouragement, but, beyond that, it was really up to them.‚Äù The goal was to be akin to a church, ‚Äúwhere everyone‚Äôs welcome, and we talk about important things, but it‚Äôs up to you to choose your path.‚Äù
Caldwell and her colleagues began working on various campaigns, such as helping residents of the town of Oxford successfully lobby for the renovation of a derelict basketball court. Throughout North Carolina, Down Home offered locals advice on how to communicate with government officials and notes on how to speak at meetings. As Down Home spread, sometimes as many as two hundred members would show up at a county-commission meeting. When they took to the microphone, some of them would start talking about space aliens or chemtrails. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs O.K.,‚Äù Zimmer said. ‚ÄúBecause then they talk about wanting to see a new stop sign, because their cousin‚Äîwhom the commissioners probably went to school with‚Äîalmost got run over last month.‚Äù
Down Home now has fourteen chapters. The group has been credited with helping elect enough Democrats to the state House to prevent Republicans from amassing a veto-proof supermajority. In 2023, despite Republican control of the state legislature, North Carolina lawmakers voted to expand Medicaid in the state and passed a slew of other pro-rural bills supported by Down Home. Caldwell, who is now the organization‚Äôs executive co-director, told me, ‚ÄúIf you polled our members, you might find they‚Äôre voting for very different people for President. But for the local soil-and-water board, or school board, we‚Äôre pretty aligned. That‚Äôs all we need.‚Äù
In Minnesota, an organization named ISAIAH has built a coalition of Black churches, Islamic centers, child-care providers, East African immigrants, and college students. The goal is to ‚Äúspend time together in common areas‚Äù and to ‚Äúbuild power for a multiracial democracy, caring economy, and thriving planet‚Äù by forging alliances among groups that are otherwise unlikely to encounter one another. In 2023, even though the state legislature was divided, ISAIAH successfully lobbied for one of the most generous paid family- and medical-leave bills in the nation. The group‚Äôs recently departed executive director, Doran Schrantz, told me that one reason the group has thrived is that it doesn‚Äôt limit participation to people who can pass litmus tests on such issues as abortion or L.G.B.T.Q. rights. Exclusionary tactics ‚Äúare kryptonite,‚Äù she told me. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre focussed on bread-and-butter issues that people agree on, regardless of party.‚Äù
In southern Indiana, a group named Hoosier Action has organized rural voters who pushed through legislation providing for the largest investment in mental health in the state‚Äôs history. Kate Hess Pace, the group‚Äôs executive director, told me that, when members meet with candidates, ‚Äúit‚Äôs really clear how disconnected the Democratic Party is from working-class people.‚Äù The bluest cities are often the most expensive places to live, she said, and, ‚Äúwhen our members tell stories about overdose and addiction, the Dem candidates immediately go to policy solutions. It‚Äôs like they‚Äôre incapable of meeting people emotionally. It‚Äôs the Republicans who consistently say, ‚ÄòOh, yeah, my brother‚Äôs been in and out of rehab, I understand how much that hurts.‚Äô ‚Äù
Down Home North Carolina, ISAIAH, and Hoosier Action have proved effective at increasing voter turnout for issues traditionally associated with the left. But donations from progressive groups have only rarely flowed their way. For the 2024 Presidential election, national Democrats spent $2.9 billion trying to elect Kamala Harris, in one of the most expensive campaigns in history. (Republicans spent $1.8 billion supporting Trump.) By contrast, Down Home North Carolina, ISAIAH, and Hoosier Action collectively raised just thirteen million dollars in 2024, much of it from local donors. Sarah Jaynes, the director of the Rural Democracy Initiative, a group that directs grants to local advocacy organizations, told me that ‚Äúthe Harris campaign and these big Senate races had more money than they could use‚Äîbut the groups on the ground who know people, the trusted messengers, they‚Äôre basically ignored.‚Äù
The solution, activists such as Wikler and Zimmer believe, is to reprioritize where Democratic funds and attention are spent. The successful mayoral campaign of Zohran Mamdani, the Harvard researcher Liz McKenna notes, ‚Äúwas by all accounts joyful, hopeful, creative, and reflected a real sense of collective possibility. And that emotional culture translated into a major electoral upset.‚Äù Nationally, however, there are few Democratic candidates running similar campaigns. And, when it comes to emotions, Trump seems to spark stronger feelings, on both the left and the right, than anyone else.
Ralph Reed reminded me that, for Faith & Freedom and many similar conservative organizations, there are no showy national rallies. And there‚Äôs little strictness about ideological consistency. But during elections the group turns out millions of voters. When Reed looks at the left today, he said, ‚Äúa lot of times it feels like they‚Äôre trying to hook people with big parades and free Beyonc√© concerts.‚Äù That‚Äôs not how you win, he went on. ‚ÄúYou win by offering people a set of values that give them meaning. Celebrities don‚Äôt deliver that. Small groups of neighbors do. And, as long as we‚Äôre building those groups, we‚Äôre gonna win.‚Äù ‚ô¶
news.summary: Republicans have become adept at creating broad coalitions in which supporting Trump is the only requirement. Democrats get tied up with litmus tests.
news.author: Charles Duhigg

news.title: Lucas: Trump is living rent-free in Massachusetts Gov. Maura Healey‚Äôs head
news.text:
Gov. Maura Healey ought to challenge President Donald Trump to a debate.

While he may not recall who Healey is, it is obvious that Trump is living rent-free in Healey‚Äôs head.

But he might remember that she sued him one hundred times during his first term when she was attorney general and would sue him a hundred times more if she could. It‚Äôs a fixation.

So, the only way to clear her head is to meet the president face-to-face, mano-a-mano, so to speak, and straighten things out. It would be like an intervention.

It won‚Äôt happen, of course, but such a meeting could work wonders.

It worked for Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, a fellow Democrat critic of Trump who met with him and it greatly benefited her state economically.

Whitmer was a strong Joe Biden supporter, as was Healey, and was chosen to give the party‚Äôs response to Trump‚Äôs state of the union address in his first term

Since talking with Trump and making nice with him, Trump approved an $850 million windfall for the state that rescued an airbase and six hundred jobs, and also backed a program to save the fish in Lake Michigan.

Trump also appointed Whitmer to the Council of Governors, a bipartisan group of ten governors who work with the federal government on critical national issues like homeland security and National Guard operations.

There was a time when Whitmer, like foppish California Gov. Gavin Newson, could not put two sentences together without attacking Trump.

That‚Äôs Healey today, a broken record. If something is not working, it is Trump‚Äôs fault.

It‚Äôs like listening to Boston Mayor Michelle Wu whine about the Massachusetts Legislature not giving her what she wants. Enough already.

Just do your job, as Bill Belichick used to say.

Trump, not her, Healey says, is to blame for everything, even though she has been governor for almost four years.

Take for example her announcement about seeking reelection the other day. Healey said, ‚ÄúThese are tough times and Donald Trump is making everything worse.‚Äù

She liked the line so much she repeated it in her ‚ÄúState of the State‚Äù speech Thursday night before a packed audience in the chamber of the Massachusetts House.

But, given her plan to make Trump her 2026 opponent rather than the Republican who will run against her, Healey has twisted her attacks on Trump into insult and mockery.

Talking about high cost of living in Massachusetts, Healey said, ‚ÄúWashington is only making it worse. We have president who throws tantrums like a two-year-old. And I‚Äôm sorry to all the two-year-olds out there.‚Äù

She also went after Trump on ICE, emotionally repeating less than accurate information about what ICE has been doing in its campaign to rid the country of criminal illegal immigrants.

One would have thought that it was Trump, and not Joe Biden, who opened the borders to the illegal immigrant invasion that overwhelmed her administration, costing the taxpayers billions while destabilizing Massachusetts.

But there was no mention of any of that.

Healey‚Äôs problem is that she has no Democrats to praise. Joe Biden, Kamala Harris, Tim Walz, all of whom she supported, are all pathetic losers. The only winner around is Donald Trump.

So, she takes her envy, hate and frustration out on him, hoping that dragging him down will raise her up.

It might work. Healey may be reelected. But Trump will still be around. So good luck with that.

Veteran political reporter Peter Lucas can be reached at: peter.lucas@bostonherald.com.
news.summary: Gov. Maura Healey ought to challenge President Donald Trump to a debate.
news.author: Peter Lucas

news.title: Republican calls growing for deeper investigation into fatal Minneapolis shooting
news.text:
WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî A growing number of Republicans are pressing for a deeper investigation into federal immigration tactics in Minnesota after a U.S. Border Patrol agent fatally shot a man in Minneapolis, a sign that the Trump administration‚Äôs accounting of events may face bipartisan scrutiny.

House Homeland Security Committee Chairman Andrew Garbarino sought testimony from leaders at Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Customs and Border Protection and U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, saying ‚Äúmy top priority remains keeping Americans safe.‚Äù

A host of other congressional Republicans, including Rep. Michael McCaul of Texas and Sens. Thom Tillis of North Carolina, Bill Cassidy of Louisiana, Susan Collins of Maine and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, pressed for more information. Their statements, in addition to concern expressed from several Republican governors, reflected a party struggling with how to respond to Saturday‚Äôs fatal shooting of Alex Pretti, a 37-year-old intensive care nurse at a VA hospital.

Trump administration officials were quick to cast Pretti as the instigator. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem was among those who said Pretti ‚Äúapproached‚Äù immigration officers with a gun and acted violently. Videos from the scene show Pretti being pushed by an officer and then a half-dozen agents descend on him. During the scuffle, he is holding a phone but is never seen brandishing the 9mm semiautomatic handgun police say he was licensed to carry.

The killing has raised uncomfortable questions about the GOP‚Äôs core positions on issues ranging from gun ownership to states‚Äô rights and trust in the federal government.

Cassidy, who is facing a Trump-backed challenger in his reelection bid, said on social media that the shooting was ‚Äúincredibly disturbing‚Äù and that the ‚Äúcredibility of ICE and DHS are at stake.‚Äù He pushed for ‚Äúa full joint federal and state investigation.‚Äù Tillis, who is not seeking reelection, urged a ‚Äúthorough and impartial investigation‚Äù and said ‚Äúany administration official who rushes to judgment and tries to shut down an investigation before it begins are doing an incredible disservice to the nation and to President Trump‚Äôs legacy.‚Äù

Murkowski called for an investigation and added that ‚ÄúICE agents do not have carte blanche in carrying out their duties.‚Äù Collins, the only incumbent Republican senator facing reelection in a state Democrat Kamala Harris carried in 2024, said a probe is needed ‚Äúto determine whether or not excessive force was used in a situation that may have been able to be diffused without violence.‚Äù

While calling for protesters to ‚Äúkeep space‚Äù from law enforcement and not interfere, Collins said federal law enforcement must ‚Äúrecognize both the public‚Äôs right to protest and the highly charged situation they now face.‚Äù

Even Sen. Pete Ricketts, a staunch ally of President Donald Trump, called for a ‚Äúprioritized, transparent investigation.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy support for funding ICE remains the same,‚Äù the Nebraska Republican, who is up for reelection, said online. ‚ÄúBut we must also maintain our core values as a nation, including the right to protest and assemble.‚Äù

Trump and other administration officials remained firm in their defense of the hard-line immigration enforcement tactics in Minneapolis, blaming Democrats in the state along with local law enforcement for not working with them. Many Republicans either echoed that sentiment or stayed silent.

In a lengthy social media post on Sunday evening, Trump called on Minnesota‚Äôs Democratic leadership to ‚Äúformally cooperate‚Äù with his administration and pressed Congress to ban so-called sanctuary cities.

The White House will likely face at least some GOP pushback

Trump has enjoyed nearly complete loyalty from fellow Republicans during his first year back in the White House. But the positions staked out in the wake of the shooting signal the administration will face at least some pushback within the party in its swift effort to define Pretti, who protested Trump‚Äôs immigration crackdown, as a violent demonstrator.

Deputy White House chief of staff Stephen Miller issued social media posts referencing an ‚Äúassassin‚Äù and ‚Äúdomestic terrorist‚Äù while Noem said Pretti showed up to ‚Äúimpede a law enforcement operation.‚Äù

At a minimum, some Republicans are calling for a de-escalation in Minneapolis.

Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt told CNN‚Äôs ‚ÄúState of the Union‚Äù that the shooting was a ‚Äúreal tragedy‚Äù and Trump needs to define an ‚Äúend game.‚Äù

‚ÄúNobody likes the feds coming to their states,‚Äù Stitt said. ‚ÄúAnd so what is the goal right now? Is it to deport every single non-U.S. citizen? I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs what Americans want.‚Äù

Vermont Gov. Phil Scott said the shooting was ‚Äúnot acceptable.‚Äù

‚ÄúAt best, these federal immigration operations are a complete failure of coordination of acceptable public safety and law enforcement practices, training and leadership,‚Äù he said in a post. ‚ÄúAt worst, it‚Äôs deliberate federal intimidation and incitement of American citizens.‚Äù

Echoing criticism that local law enforcement isn‚Äôt cooperating with federal officials, Rep. James Comer, R-Ky., suggested the administration focus its immigration efforts elsewhere.

‚ÄúIf I were President Trump, I would almost think about if the mayor and the governor are going to put our ICE officials in harm‚Äôs way and there‚Äôs a chance of losing more innocent lives or whatever, then maybe go to another city and let the people of Minneapolis decide do we want to continue to have all these illegals?‚Äù he told ‚ÄúSunday Morning Futures‚Äù on the Fox News Channel. ‚ÄúI think the people of Minnesota would rebel against their leadership.‚Äù

A sensitive moment for the GOP

Pretti‚Äôs killing comes at a sensitive moment for the GOP as the party prepares for a challenging midterm election year. Trump has fomented a sense of chaos on the world stage, bringing the NATO alliance to the brink last week. Domestically, Trump has struggled to respond to widespread affordability concerns.

Meanwhile, approval of his handling of immigration ‚Äî long a political asset for the president and the GOP ‚Äî has tumbled. Just 38% of U.S. adults approved of how Trump was handling immigration in January, down from 49% in March, according to an AP-NORC poll.

The killing spurred notable tension with the GOP‚Äôs long-standing support for gun rights. Officials say Pretti was armed, but no bystander videos that have surfaced so far appear to show him holding a weapon. The Minneapolis police chief said Pretti had a permit to carry a gun.

Yet administration officials, including Noem and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, have questioned why he was armed. Speaking on ABC‚Äôs ‚ÄúThis Week‚Äù Bessent said that when he has attended protests, ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt bring a gun. I brought a billboard.‚Äù

Such comments were notable for a party where support for the Second Amendment‚Äôs protection of gun ownership is foundational. Indeed, many in the GOP, including Trump, lifted Kyle Rittenhouse into prominence when the then-17-year-old former police youth cadet shot three men, killing two of them, during a 2020 protest in Wisconsin against police brutality. He was acquitted of all charges after testifying that he acted in self defense.

In the wake of Pretti‚Äôs killing, gun rights advocates noted that it is legal to carry firearms during protests.

‚ÄúEvery peaceable Minnesotan has the right to keep and bear arms ‚Äî including while attending protests, acting as observers, or exercising their First Amendment rights,‚Äù the Minnesota Gun Owners Caucus said in a statement. ‚ÄúThese rights do not disappear when someone is lawfully armed.‚Äù

In a social media post, the National Rifle Association said ‚Äúresponsible public voices should be awaiting a full investigation, not making generalizations and demonizing law-abiding citizens.‚Äù

Rep. Thomas Massie, R-Ky., who is often critical of the White House, said ‚Äúcarrying a firearm is not a death sentence.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Constitutionally protected God-given right,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúand if you don‚Äôt understand this you have no business in law enforcement or government.

The second-ranking Justice Department official said he was aware of reports that Pretti was lawfully armed.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing wrong with anybody lawfully carrying firearms,‚Äù Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche said on ‚ÄúMeet the Press‚Äù on NBC. ‚ÄúBut just make no mistake about it, this was an incredibly split-second decision that had to be made by ICE officers.‚Äù
news.summary: The Trump administration accused a VA nurse of instigating the shooting.
news.author: The Associated Press

news.title: Trump‚Äôs bounce among Hispanics can benefit him in the midterm elections¬†
news.text:
One explanation is that Hispanics enthusiastically support the Trump administration‚Äôs recent capture of Venezuela‚Äôs tyrant, Nicolas Maduro. A new Morning Consult poll found that 66% of Hispanics supported the move, the highest level of approval of any racial group. White people, for example, supported the president‚Äôs decision at 64%. The triumphant military operation saw elite U.S. commandos dive into the heart of a foreign country and snatch a dictator and enemy of America without suffering a single loss. It‚Äôs no surprise that such an exhibition of strength and competence would play well with voters.

The public has become increasingly skeptical of foreign interventions in recent years, but they like to win. Hispanic people are no exception.

Trump‚Äôs efforts to secure the border and crack down on drug trafficking and violent crime have also received favorable support in this demographic group. Under the Biden administration, America‚Äôs southern border became a playground for narcoterrorist organizations, with predictable results. Americans of all ethnicities became less safe as their communities deteriorated. 

Trump has restored sovereignty, worked to seal the border, and taken the fight to the doorstep of those who peddle the poison that kills thousands of Americans. The status quo was neither working nor sustainable, and the public knew it.

Unsurprisingly, a majority supports securing the border. So, too, do the Hispanic voters who have played a key role in Trump‚Äôs political fortunes. 

In 2024, Trump received a record share of their votes at 43%. While not as high as his Democratic opponent, Kamala Harris, this is a higher percentage than any Republican candidate in modern history, and an 8-point increase from 2020. It could be the start of something big for Trump and the Republican Party, possibly giving both a needed boost as they look ahead to a difficult midterm.

For decades, the Republican Party has sought to attract Latinos and other minority voters who had long been part of the Democratic coalition. George W. Bush, for example, made a concerted effort to bring Hispanics into the tent, seeking to use immigration reform and other measures to do so. Trump‚Äôs approach has been altogether different. 

WHITE HOUSE REPORT CARD: FOREIGN SUCCESSES AND SABER-RATTLING OVER GREENLAND

He has sought to remake the Republican Party as the champion of the working class, willing to address the ‚Äúroot cause‚Äù of illegal immigration. This has been key to winning over voters whom the Democratic Party took for granted. 

Bringing them into the GOP alone won‚Äôt be enough to bring the party victoriously across the finish line. Its fate will hinge on the economy and prices, as voters will hold the ruling party accountable. But Trump‚Äôs rebalancing of relations with Latin America, which includes toppling Maduro and deporting illegal immigrants who taint legal immigrants, can be an element in winning Hispanic votes next November. If Trump can lower the cost of living, he will likely hold his gains among Hispanics.
news.summary: It has recently been a bad stretch for President Donald Trump, perhaps the worst of his second term. But recent polls showing a bump in support from Hispanic voters might offer a path forward. The latest Emerson College survey has Trump‚Äôs approval rate surging among Hispanic voters. Emerson found that 43.3% of Hispanics approved of […]
news.author: Washington Examiner

news.title: I'm obsessed with these 5 pop culture podcasts ‚Äîand one just won a Golden Globe
news.text:
If you needed proof of the ever-growing Hollywood legitimacy of podcasts, a Golden Globes win should do it. Along with its usual tributes to excellence in film and television, this year's Golden Globes ceremony expanded for the first time into the audio space via its newest category, Best Podcast.

In case you missed it, "Good Hang with Amy Poehler" claimed that inaugural award, cementing the not-even-a-year-old series as a formidable player in the entertainment world. This historic win highlights a broader trend: podcasts are no longer just a side project for stars, but a primary destination for raw interviews and cultural commentary.

Along with Poehler's award-winning show, here are five great pop culture podcasts you should add to your rotation.

'Good Hang with Amy Poehler'

Amy Poehler, the beloved comedienne from "Saturday Night Live," "Parks and Recreation" and funny flicks like "Mean Girls," "Baby Mama" and the "Inside Out" franchise, launched her sweet interview series "Good Hang" in March 2025, inviting close pals ‚Äî who just happen to be some of Hollywood's biggest comedic power players ‚Äî like Tina Fey, Martin Short, Jack Black and Kathryn Hahn to appear in the show's early episodes.

In the past year, Poehler has expanded that subject pool to politics (Michelle Obama), cooking (Ina Garten), music (The Jonas Brothers), directing (Ryan Coogler) and more, but through it all, the lighthearted yet insightful format has remained, with engaging sit-downs about her interviewee's professional wit.

"Good Hang with Amy Poehler" on Spotify

'SmartLess'

There's not one but three big-name celebrities at the helm of "SmartLess": actors and longtime buddies Jason Bateman, Sean Hayes and Will Arnett. Every week since the show debuted on July 20, 2020, one of the fellas invites a surprise celebrity guest to the program and reveals their identity at the top of the episode to the other two hosts before kicking off their characteristically disarming and humorous conversations about personal life, professional career and more.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have any format, there‚Äôs no preamble,‚Äù Arnett declared during a 2021 installment of the show. There‚Äôs no theme, there‚Äôs no goal. I‚Äôve been winging it since 1970, why would I start now?"

The trio had produced more than 300 episodes over the past half-decade, with illustrious interviewees like George Clooney, Kamala Harris, Paul McCartney, Jennifer Aniston, Steven Spielberg, Billie Eilish and more.

"SmartLess" on Apple Podcasts

'The Basement Yard'

"The Basement Yard" differs from other pop culture podcasts on this list as its hosts aren't of the traditional celebrity mold ‚Äî rather, the weekly comedy podcast is emceed by YouTube vlogger Joe Santagato and his childhood BFF Frank Alvarez ‚Äî and it's less of an interview show and more a chance for the two lifelong friends to engage with pop culture through viral clips, spirited debates, nostalgic discussions and other funny segments.

The podcast has grown and shifted in the decade since Santagato first started it as a solo show. Its most recent iteration was a live tour that sold out notable venues like Madison Square Garden and Radio City Music Hall in their native New York City.

"The Basement Yard" on Apple Podcasts

"Call Her Daddy"

Alex Cooper has become podcast powerhouse via "Call Her Daddy," the Golden Globe-nominated sex, relationship and entertainment series she launched in 2018 with then-co-host Sofia Franklyn. Franklyn departed the project in 2020, prior to Cooper's $60 million deal to exclusively present the podcast on Spotify in 2021, which she more than doubled in a $125 million distribution and advertising deal with Sirius XM three years later.

Via her raw, unfiltered discussions with celebrities like Kim Kardashian, Miley Cyrus, Gwyneth Paltrow, Charlize Theron and Chappell Roan, among many others, Cooper's podcast manages to get intimate insights into these mega-stars' personal lives, delving into everything from toxic relationships to sexual identity to mental health struggles and more.

"Call Her Daddy" on SiriusXM

'Conan O'Brien Needs a Friend'

Thanks to his lengthy late-night career, Conan O'Brien certainly knows how to conduct a fun interview with a celebrity guest, but his weekly podcast "Conan O'Brien Needs a Friend" allows him to get "deeper, unboundedly playful, and free from FCC regulations" in trying to establish "real and lasting friendship" with his famous subjects.

Co-hosted by O'Brien's longtime assistant-turned-friend Sona Movsesian and producer Matt Gourley, the podcast has seen Conan pal around with Matt Damon, Ben Stiller, Rose Byrne, Janelle James, Ted Danson, Leanne Morgan and Will Ferrell, his first-ever guest when the series premiered back in 2018.

"Conan O'Brien Needs a Friend" on Spotify

Follow Tom's Guide on Google News and add us as a preferred source to get our up-to-date news, analysis, and reviews in your feeds. 

More from Tom's Guide

news.summary: I could listen to these 5 pop culture podcasts all day long ‚Äî and one just made Golden Globes history.
news.author: Christina Izzo

news.title: Two comedians told the truth about Jasmine Crockett's campaign
news.text:
This month, some of the worst elements of 2020-style online progressive politics made a brief return, thanks to a controversy involving a couple of comedians and U.S. Rep. Jasmine Crockett of Texas. It merits attention, despite its seeming triviality, because the underlying issue could cost Democrats the Senate this fall.

The contretemps started with an offhand comment on ‚ÄúLas Culturistas,‚Äù a podcast hosted by actors and comedians Bowen Yang, until recently a star on ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live,‚Äù and Matt Rogers. Rogers was dunking on Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, arguing that Democrats need genuinely populist leaders, not those who simply excel at trolling Donald Trump. From there, he dismissed Crockett‚Äôs campaign to move up to the Senate.

‚ÄúAnytime a politician is making it too obviously about themselves, I‚Äôm already done,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd don‚Äôt waste your money sending to Jasmine Crockett. Do not do it.‚Äù Yang added, ‚ÄúI must agree.‚Äù

Online, there was a backlash from Crockett fans, many of whom accused the ‚ÄúLas Culturistas‚Äù hosts of racism and misogyny. The reaction was intense enough that both Rogers and Yang issued abject apologies. ‚ÄúI have great respect and admiration for Rep. Crockett,‚Äù wrote Rogers, who promised to ‚Äúbe better.‚Äù Yang pledged to use his platform ‚Äúmore responsibly.‚Äù

But Rogers and Yang were right to be skeptical of Crockett, who almost certainly cannot win a general election in Texas. Those who disagree have every right to criticize them, and me. But progressives shouldn‚Äôt let a retrograde style of internet discourse inhibit them from pointing out the obvious.

It can be tricky, of course, to discuss electability concerns about Black women candidates. It‚Äôs not always easy to draw the line between analyzing the voters‚Äô putative prejudices and reifying them. If liberals decide in advance that Black women are at an electoral disadvantage, they risk making that disadvantage real. But it‚Äôs not race and gender that make Crockett a bad candidate, though both obviously shape perceptions of her. The problem with Crockett is that her theory about how Democrats can win Texas is wrong.

I understand why lots of Democrats adore Crockett. She‚Äôs charismatic and often funny and knows how to command attention. ‚ÄúI think that we have to take a page or two, or three or four, out of Donald Trump‚Äôs book,‚Äù she told Vanity Fair in 2024. Some of her insults are in bad taste ‚Äî she has called Texas Gov. Greg Abbott, who uses a wheelchair, ‚ÄúHot Wheels‚Äù ‚Äî but it‚Äôs easy to see why Democrats who feel brutalized by Trump want champions willing to go low.

Still, Democrats cannot win Texas, a state where Trump beat Kamala Harris by almost 14 percentage points, without flipping at least some Republican voters. James Talarico, Crockett‚Äôs opponent in the Democratic primary, showed that he could do that in his 2018 election to the Texas House, turning a red seat blue and winning a district that was also carried by Abbott.

Crockett, by contrast, has always represented a deep blue district and has never had to run a seriously contested general election.

She has been openly contemptuous not just of Trump, but also of the Texans who cast their ballots for him. In that Vanity Fair interview, she described Latino voters who agreed with Trump‚Äôs pitch on immigration ‚Äî a demographic where Democrats need to make inroads ‚Äî as having a ‚Äúslave mentality.‚Äù

Rather than focusing on peeling off Trump voters, Crockett is staking her candidacy on a promise to motivate Texans who rarely if ever go to the polls. ‚ÄúThe theory of my case has always been that we could expand the electorate,‚Äù she told a Texas news station last month. ‚ÄúWe could get people that normally don‚Äôt participate in politics to be excited about getting involved.‚Äù

This theory is dubious. In a detailed article last month, Texas Monthly called the idea that Democrats can prevail in the state simply by juicing turnout ‚Äúthe biggest lie in Texas politics.‚Äù It noted that in 2018, when Beto O‚ÄôRourke came close to defeating Republican Sen. Ted Cruz, he did so by winning over hundreds of thousands of Abbott voters who split their tickets. In that year‚Äôs midterms, races across the country saw presidential-level turnout. But much of the reason there was a blue wave, according to Democratic data firm Catalist, was that swing voters who‚Äôd opted for Trump in 2016 then supported Democrats two years later.

Of course, some candidates have succeeded in part by inspiring low-propensity voters, most notably Trump and New York Mayor Zohran Mamdani. Both were outsider candidates who were able to motivate people who distrust conventional politicians. Crockett, however, isn‚Äôt offering an alternative to the Democratic Party‚Äôs status quo.

In Vanity Fair, she described Harris as a ‚Äúperfect candidate‚Äù who ‚Äúdid everything right‚Äù and whose main flaw was a failure to get her message across. The video announcing Crockett‚Äôs candidacy featured a close-up of her face with audio of Trump insulting her. Trump‚Äôs disdain is indeed a badge of honor, but it is probably not enough to activate voters who couldn‚Äôt be bothered to vote against him when he was on the ballot.

Texas is a difficult environment for Democrats, but there are a lot of disaffected Trump voters in the state; according to the Texas Politics Project, the president‚Äôs approval ratings are underwater there by 7 percentage points. Crockett, however, is poorly positioned to pick up Trump defectors. In November, 49 percent of Texas voters told pollsters they would definitely not vote for her. Only 40 percent said that of Talarico.

Such numbers may explain why Republicans, according to the political news site NOTUS, worked behind the scenes to push Crockett into the race. The National Republican Senatorial Committee disseminated polls showing her winning a potential primary. Further, an anonymous source told NOTUS, Republicans ran an AstroTurf phone and text campaign urging Democrats to contact Crockett and ask her to run. Those efforts may have worked. ‚ÄúThe more I saw the poll results, I couldn‚Äôt ignore the trends which were clear,‚Äù Crockett said in her announcement speech.

Speaking to The Washington Post this week, Crockett seemed to suggest that the race was such a long shot that Democrats could afford to take chances. Addressing her critics, she said: ‚ÄúIf you think it‚Äôs a losing cause, then who cares? But at least you could say we tried something new and we learned something from this experience.‚Äù

This gets things backward. Texas is not a lost cause, and Democrats cannot afford to treat it like one, given that they must flip four Republican seats if they are to retake the Senate.

If people hesitate to make the case against Crockett because they fear online pile-ons, only Republicans benefit. There is very little that‚Äôs good to say about Elon Musk‚Äôs transformation of Twitter into a white nationalist propaganda factory, but one tiny silver lining is that it has lessened the platform‚Äôs malign influence on progressive politics. As Politico reported this week, now Republicans are the ones dealing with the site‚Äôs toxic dynamics, as esoteric debates and influencer feuds tear at the MAGA movement.

But social media is much bigger than X, and the ‚ÄúLas Culturistas‚Äù episode shows that bad-faith social justice arguments still have a lot of power on the internet. The fault for this lies not with the people making those arguments, but with those who let themselves be cowed by them.
news.summary: This month, some of the worst elements of 2020-style online progressive politics made a brief return, thanks to a controversy involving a couple of comedians and U.S. Rep. Jasmine Crockett of Texas. It merits attention, despite its seeming triviality, because‚Ä¶
news.author: By Michelle Goldberg,Daniel Ribar ‚Äî The New York Times
